{{Flu}}
The '''1968 flu pandemic''' was a [[Pandemic Severity Index|category 2]] [[flu pandemic]] whose outbreak in 1968 and 1969 killed an estimated one million people worldwide.<ref>{{cite book |last=Paul |first=William E. |title=Fundamental Immunology |pages=1273 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oPSG1PGmZUkC}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/usandworld/43705182.html |title=World health group issues alert Mexican president tries to isolate those with swine flu |date=April 25, 2009 |publisher=Associated Press |accessdate=2009-04-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427103848/http://www.jsonline.com/news/usandworld/43705182.html |archivedate=April 27, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.torontosun.com/news/columnists/michele_mandel/2009/04/26/9248411-sun.html |title=No need to panic ... yet Ontario officials are worried swine flu could be pandemic, killing thousands |last=Mandel |first=Michael |date=April 26, 2009 |publisher=Toronto Sun |accessdate=2009-04-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427101524/http://www.torontosun.com/news/columnists/michele_mandel/2009/04/26/9248411-sun.html |archivedate=April 27, 2009 |df= }}</ref> It was caused by an [[H3N2]] strain of the [[influenza A virus]], descended from [[H2N2]] through [[antigenic shift]], a [[genetics|genetic]] process in which [[gene]]s from multiple subtypes [[Reassortment|reassorted]] to form a new virus. Because it originated in [[British Hong Kong|Hong Kong]], the pandemic is also referred to as '''Hong Kong flu'''.
==The 1968–1969 pandemic== The first record of the outbreak in [[British Hong Kong|Hong Kong]] appeared on 13 July 1968. By the end of July 1968, extensive outbreaks were reported in [[Vietnam]] and [[Singapore]]. Despite the fatality of the 1957 [[Asian Flu]] in [[China]], little improvement had been made regarding the handling of such [[epidemic]]s. ''[[The Times]]'' newspaper was actually the first source to sound alarm regarding this new possible [[pandemic]].
By September 1968, the flu reached [[India]], the [[Philippines]], northern [[Australia]] and [[Europe]]. That same month, the virus entered [[California]] from returning [[Vietnam War]] [[United States Military|troops]] but did not become widespread in the [[United States]] until December 1968. It would reach [[Japan]], Africa and South America by 1969.<ref name="Starling" /> The outbreak in Hong Kong, where density is about 500 people per acre, reached maximum intensity in two weeks, lasting six months in total from July to December 1968, however worldwide deaths from this virus peaked much later, in December 1968 and January 1969. By that time, public health warnings<ref>{{Citation |first=F. Avery |last=Jones |title=Winter Epidemics |journal=[[British Medical Journal]] |year=1968 |volume=1968 |issue=4 |pages=327 |doi=10.1136/bmj.4.5626.327-c }}.</ref> and virus descriptions<ref>{{Citation |last=Coleman |first=Marion T. |last2=Dowdle |first2=Walter R. |last3=Pereira |first3=Helio G. |last4=Schild |first4=Geoffrey C. |last5=Chang |first5=W. K. |last6= |first6= |title=The Hong Kong/68 Influenza A2 Variant |journal=[[The Lancet]] |volume=292 |issue=7583 |year=1968 |pages=1384–1386 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(68)92683-4 }}.</ref> were issued in the scientific and medical journals.
In comparison to other pandemics, the Hong Kong flu yielded a low death rate, with a [[case-fatality ratio]] below 0.5% making it a category 2 disease on the [[Pandemic Severity Index]]. The pandemic infected an estimated 500,000 Hong Kong residents, 15% of the population.<ref name="Starling">{{cite book |last=Starling |first=Arthur |title=Plague, SARS, and the Story of Medicine in Hong Kong |publisher=HK University Press |year=2006 |isbn=962-209-805-3 |page=55 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WBx6McA35iYC}}</ref> In the United States, approximately 33,800 people died,<ref>{{cite web |publisher=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services |url=http://www.pandemicflu.gov/general/historicaloverview.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331065518/http://www.pandemicflu.gov/general/historicaloverview.html |archivedate=2009-03-31 |title=Pandemics and Pandemic Threats since 1900}}</ref> including [[conjoined twins]] [[Daisy and Violet Hilton]] in January 1969.
The same virus returned the following years: a year later, in late 1969 and early 1970, and in 1972.
Fewer people died during this pandemic than the two previous pandemics for various reasons:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/security/ops/hsc-scen-3_pandemic-1968.htm|title=1968 Hong Kong Flu|first=John|last=Pike|date=|website=www.globalsecurity.org|accessdate=26 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170324200512/http://www.globalsecurity.org/security/ops/hsc-scen-3_pandemic-1968.htm|archivedate=24 March 2017|df=}}</ref> # some immunity against the N2 flu virus may have been retained in populations struck by the [[Asian Flu]] strains which had been circulating since 1957; # the pandemic did not gain momentum until near the winter school holidays, thus limiting the infection spreading; # improved [[medical care]] gave vital support to the very ill; # the availability of [[antibiotics]] that were more effective against [[Secondary infection|secondary bacterial infections]].
== Clinical data == Flu symptoms lasted four to five days (some symptoms lasted up to two weeks).<ref name="Starling" /> Those over the age of 65 were most likely to die.
== Virology == [[File:Influenza virus.png|thumb|300px|right|The [[influenza]] [[virus]]es that caused the Hong Kong flu. (magnified approximately 100,000 times)]] The Hong Kong flu was the first known outbreak of the [[H3N2]] strain, though there is serologic evidence of H3N1 infections [[Www.goo.gl.com/|in]] the late 19th century. The virus was isolated in [[Queen Mary Hospital, Hong Kong|Queen Mary Hospital]].
In the 1968 pandemic vaccine became available one month after the outbreaks peaked in the US.
Both the [[H2N2]] and H3N2 [[pandemic flu]] strains contained genes from [[avian influenza]] viruses. The new subtypes arose in pigs coinfected with avian and human viruses and were soon transferred to humans. Swine were considered the original "intermediate host" for influenza, because they supported reassortment of divergent subtypes. However, other hosts appear capable of similar coinfection (e.g., many poultry species), and direct transmission of avian viruses to humans is possible. H1N1 may have been transmitted directly from birds to humans (Belshe 2005).<ref>[http://www.influenzareport.com/ir/ai.htm Chapter Two : Avian Influenza by Timm C. Harder and Ortrud Werner] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510091835/http://www.influenzareport.com/ir/ai.htm |date=2016-05-10 }} from excellent free on-line Book called ''Influenza Report 2006'' which is a medical textbook that provides a comprehensive overview of epidemic and pandemic influenza.''</ref>
The Hong Kong flu strain shared internal genes and the [[Neuraminidase deficiency|neuraminidase]] with the 1957 [[Asian Flu]] ([[H2N2]]). Accumulated antibodies to the neuraminidase or internal proteins may have resulted in much fewer casualties than most [[pandemic]]s. However, cross-immunity within and between subtypes of influenza is poorly understood.
"Three strains of Hong Kong influenza virus isolated from humans were compared with a strain isolated from a calf for their ability to cause disease in calves. One of the human strains. A/Aichi/2/68, was detected for five days in a calf, but all three failed to cause signs of disease. Strain A/cal/Duschanbe/55/71 could be detected for seven days and caused an influenza-like illness in calves."<ref>{{Citation |last=Campbell |first=Charles H. |last2=Easterday |first2=Bernard C. |last3=Webster |first3=Robert G. |year=1977 |title=Strains of Hong Kong Influenza Virus in Calves |journal=Journal of Infectious Diseases |volume=135 |issue=4 |pages=678–680 |doi=10.2307/30107903 |pmid=853249 }}.</ref>
==See also== *[[Influenza vaccine]] *[[Influenza A virus subtype H3N2]]

'''Abortion in Italy''' became legal in May 1978, when [[Italy|Italian]] women were allowed to terminate a [[pregnancy]] on request during the first 90 days. A proposal to repeal the law was considered in a 1981 national referendum, but was rejected by nearly 68% of voters; another referendum aimed at eliminating the restrictions was rejected by 88.4%.http://www.iub.edu/~kinsey/ccies/it.php#contracep Italian women are eligible to request an abortion for health, economic or social reasons, including the circumstances under which conception occurred. Abortions are performed free-of-charge in public hospitals or in private structures authorized by the regional health authorities. The law also allows termination in the second trimester of the pregnancy only when the life of the woman would be at risk if the pregnancy is carried to term or the fetus carries genetic or other serious malformations which would put the mother at risk of serious psychological or physical consequences. The law states that, unless a state of emergency requires immediate intervention, a period of seven days, not compulsory, has to occur between the medical authorization and the effective date of the termination. Although the law only permits pregnancy termination to women at least eighteen years old, it also includes provisions for women younger than eighteen, who can request the intervention of a judge when the legal tutor refuses the intervention, or there are reasons to exclude the legal tutor from the process. The judge has to make a decision within five days of the request. Women younger than eighteen don't need parental consent in case of urgent situation or after 90 days. ==Legal induced abortions== Since 1980, the [[Laboratory]] of Epidemiology and Biostatistics at the High Institute of Health (Istituto Superiore di Sanità, ISS) in Rome has maintained a surveillance system for legal induced abortions. This system is based on quarterly reporting by the regional health authorities. A standardized form is compiled that contains aggregate data on major social-demographic characteristics of the woman (age, residency status, marital status, reproductive history) as well as details about the procedure (weeks of gestation, whether the procedure is elective or performed on an emergency basis, where certification was issued, type of procedure and location where it was performed, duration of stay, and immediate complications). This information is then sent to the ISS, which examines data quality and performs data analysis of trends, geographic distribution, and characteristics of women undergoing abortion. These analyses are performed annually by the ISS and the Ministry of Health (MH) and presented by the Minister of Health to the Parliament; results are also published in ISTISAN reports, an official publication of the ISS. Italy is considered to have one of the most accurate and timely abortion surveillance systems in the world. ==Abortion rate== In 1993, the [[abortion]] ratio in Italy was 9.8 per 1,000 live births, less than 1% (Table 2). However, this measure also varies regionally. The central and northern regions (in particular [[Emilia-Romagna]], [[Liguria]] and [[Tuscany]]) are characterized by relatively low TFRs (one lifetime birth per woman), high abortion rates and elevated abortion ratios. While low levels of fertility can also be found in some of the northwestern regions, abortion rates are moderate in these regions (9-12 abortions per 1,000); therefore, abortion ratios in a few of these areas are closer to the national level. Subsequent to the legalization of abortion in Italy in 1978, abortion rates among Italian women first rose and then declined steadily, from a peak of 16.9 abortions per 1,000 women of reproductive age in 1983 to 9.8 per 1,000 in 1993. Abortion rates vary considerably by [[geographic]] region, with rates typically highest in the more secular regions and lowest in regions where [[traditional values]] predominate. Data from 1981 and 1991 indicate that age-specific abortion rates decreased during the 1980s for all age-groups, with the largest declines occurring in regions with the highest levels of [[abortion]]. Moreover, a shift in the age distribution of abortion rates occurred during the 1980s, with women aged 30–34 registering the highest abortion rate in 1991, whereas in 1981 the highest level of abortion occurred among those aged 25–29. The abortion rate among adolescent women was low at both times (7.6 per 1,000 in 1981 and 4.6 per 1,000 in 1991). These data are based only on reported legal abortions; the number of clandestine abortions remains unknown. A phenomenon to emerge in recent years has been an increase in the number of abortions requested by immigrant women. Among the 138,357 abortions performed in 1993, 13,826 (10%) involved foreign residents, an increase from 9,850 in 1996. This increase is most likely due to the rising number of immigrant women in Italy; the resident permits, for example, according to the data of the National Statistics Institute (ISTAT), have increased from 678,000 in 1995 to 1,100,000 in 1999. Based on estimates of the population of immigrant women 18–49 years of age, Istat has calculated that the AR for immigrant women was 28.7/1000 in 1998, approximately three times higher than that observed in Italian citizens. Indeed, the increase in the numbers of immigrant women may be the main cause of the leveling-off of the abortion rate in Italy. If the analysis of trends is limited to 1996-1998, years for which information is most complete on residency status, the number of abortions in Italian women declined from 127,700 in 1996 to 123,728 in 1998. ==Abortion incidence== In 1993, approximately 140,000 induced abortions were performed in Italy. In comparison, the average annual number during the period 1982-1984 was more than 230,000. Similar patterns can also be seen in abortion rates. After legalization, abortion rates rose modestly, increasing from 13.7 abortions per 1,000 women aged 15–44 in 1979 to a peak of 16.9 per 1,000 in 1982 and 1983. During the period 1982-1984, Italian abortion rates stabilized, and this period was followed by a steady decline: By 1986, the rate had dropped to 14.0 abortions per 1,000 women, and by 1990 it had reached 11.1 per 1,000; by 1993, the abortion rate had decreased to 9.8 per 1,000.Salvini Bettarini, Silvana. "Induced Abortion in Italy: levels, Trends, and Charastics." Guttmacher Institute . 6 Nov. 1996. Family Planning Perspectives. . {{as of|2010}}, the abortion rate was 10.0 abortions per 1000 women aged 15–44 years.{{Cite web | title = World Abortion Policies 2013 | publisher = United Nations | year = 2013 | url = https://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/publications/policy/world-abortion-policies-2013.shtml | accessdate = 3 March 2014 }} [[File:Demonstration_for_abortion_rights_in_Milan,_1975.jpg|thumb|Demonstration for abortion, in Milan 1975]] == Law n. 194== === Historical background=== Before the approval of the law, in 1978, abortion was considered to be a crime against the integrity and the bloodline, as stated in the [[Criminal code|Criminal Code]] book 2 Title X.{{Cite book|title=C'è chi dice no. Dalla leva all'aborto. Come cambia l'obiezione di coscienza (Vol. 747)|last=Lalli|first=C.|publisher=Il Saggiatore|year=2011|isbn=9788865761465|location=|pages=}} In particular, the article 546 prohibited all different type of abortions, in case of it the punishment could have been from 2 to 5 years in prison.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mondodiritto.it/codici/codice-penale/art-546-codice-penale-aborto-di-donna-consenziente.html|title=Art 546 codice penale aborto di donna consenziente »|website=Mondo Diritto|access-date=2018-05-18}} The only exception was so called, state of necessity which entails a current and imminent danger to the woman. The turning point for the [[abortion debate]] was the decision number 27 of the [[Constitutional Court of Italy|Italian Constitutional Court]] on 18 February 1975 the hat stated that article 546 is unconstitutional.{{Cite web|url=http://www.giurcost.org/decisioni/1975/0027s-75.html|title=Consulta OnLine - Sentenza n. 27 del 1975|website=www.giurcost.org|access-date=2018-05-18}} Indeed, the Court ruled that against article 546 was against article 31 of the [[Italian Constitution]], which said that: "It protects maternity, infancy and youth, promoting the institutions necessary thereto".{{Cite book|url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Italy|title=Constitution of Italy}} Moreover, article 546 is against article 32 of the Constitution, which specified that the Republic safeguards health as a fundamental right of the individual. The Italian magazine [[Panorama (magazine)|''Panorama'']], in 1974, found out that a significant number of illegal abortions was performed every year, and it suggests that all women had either an abortion or knew a friend who had it.{{Cite book|title=L'aborto in Italia: storia di una legge.|last=Scirè|first=G.|publisher=Mondadori|year=2011|isbn=9788861595231|location=|pages=}} ===Parliamentary debate=== In the early seventies with the presentation of two bills originating from the [[Italian Radicals (disambiguation)|radical left]] which aimed to legalize [[therapeutic abortion]]. These bills did not reach the discussion state before the dissolution of parliament and the calling of new elections.{{Cite book|title=L'aborto. Storia e attualità di un problema sociale|last=Flamigni|first=Carlo|publisher=Pendragon|year=2008|isbn=9788883426360|location=|pages=}} In 1973 the fight to legalize abortion was begun with the Fortuna first bill.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aggiornamentisociali.it/easyne2/LYT.aspx?Code=agso&IDLYT=769&ST=SQL&SQL=ID_Documento=1739|title=La proposta di legge Fortuna sull'aborto|language=it|access-date=2018-05-18}} Fortuna’s law provided for the possibility of therapeutic abortions but is required the agreement of 3 doctors and precludes abortion unless the woman was seriously ill or mad. It also demanded the consent of parents for girls under 18. After the election in 1976, the [[pro-abortion]] majority was committed to legalization and nine different bills were presented from June 1976 till April 1978. Finally, the bill was passed and published on 22 May 1978. ====The influence of feminism==== From the end of the 1960s, [[feminism]] played a leading role in reorganizing the terms of the debate about women and their condition. [[Abortion]] has united feminist groups which have fought to demand abortion right.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.it/books?hl=it&lr=&id=3JKQrd8hATMC&oi=fnd&pg=PA68&dq=Cadwell+abortion+italy+&ots=Days4Pwr4r&sig=A-kb3NaNM8Hz2k1qBBJgUn6OMgw#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Feminism and Materialism: Women and Modes of Production|last=Kuhn|first=Annette|last2=Wolpe|first2=AnnMarie|date=2012-10-11|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415635059|language=en}} The peak was reached between 1974 and 1976 with the mass mobilization. This coincides with the political struggle for [[abortion]], but, by the time the abortion law was passed in 1978, the major moment of activity had passed.{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-1-349-21260-6_5|title=Women and Italy|last=Caldwell|first=Lesley|date=1991|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan, London|isbn=9780333455777|series=University of Reading European and International Studies|pages=95–116|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-1-349-21260-6_5}} ==== Catholic church==== The power and strength of the [[Holy See|Vatican]] and the organized [[Catholic Church|church]] is exerted in economic and political terms, but it is also exercised at a more local level through its strength in the provision of social services and neighborhood organization. The church statement on sexuality and the family represent the most significant proportion of its public statement to the faithful. It is a central doctrinal area and one through which the church is intent on reinforcing and extending its control.{{Cite journal|last=Caldwell|first=Lesley|date=1981|title=Abortion in Italy|jstor=1394759|journal=Feminist Review|issue=7|pages=49–63|doi=10.2307/1394759}} For the church, abortion involves the destruction of human life and can never be accepted regardless of the difficulties this position imposes. This meant that the church could not admit the possibility of legal abortions.{{Cite web|url=http://heinonline.org/HOL/Page?handle=hein.journals/emint14&div=13&g_sent=1&casa_token=&collection=journals|title=Redirecting...|website=heinonline.org|access-date=2018-05-18}} The political party [[Christian Democracy (Italy)|Christian Democracy]], was the party which has governed Italy since 1948, together with the [[Italian Communist Party (2016)|Italian Communist Party’s]] interpretation of the importance of [[Catholicism]] for any analysis of the balance of forces. The council of Italian bishops issued a statement confirming the church’s position on abortion and arguing against the legalization. === The content of Law n. 194 === The law 194 on the adoption of [[social protection]] of motherhood and the voluntary termination of pregnancy.{{Cite web|url=http://www.normattiva.it/uri-res/N2Ls?urn:nir:stato:legge:1978-5-22;194!vig|title=*** NORMATTIVA ***|website=www.normattiva.it|access-date=2018-05-18}} Art. 1 stated that the State guarantees the right to responsible and planned parenthood, recognizes the social value of motherhood, and shall protect human life from the beginning.{{Cite web|url=http://www.columbia.edu/itc/history/degrazia/courseworks/legge_194.pdf|title=Law 194|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Italian legislation|website=Columbia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-18}} Moreover, the voluntary [[termination of pregnancy]] as covered by this law shall not be a means of birth control. Art. 2 regards the function of family counseling center (''consultori familiari'') and what it is their role in relation to the law. Family counselling centers shall assist any pregnant woman: * By informing her of her rights under State legislation and of the social, health and welfare services actually available from agencies. * By informing her of appropriate ways to take advantage of the provisions of labor legislation design to protect any pregnant women * By suggesting to the local agencies solution to problem relate to motherhood * By helping to overcome the factors which might lead the woman to have her pregnancy terminated. The law presents two different scenarios:{{Cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/law/help/abortion-legislation/europe.php|title=Abortion Legislation in Europe|date=January 2015|website=www.loc.gov|language=en|others=Acosta, Luis; Yatsunska-Poff, Olena; Zeldin, Wendy; Boring, Nicolas; Hofverberg, Elin; Feikert-Ahalt, Clare; Figueroa, Dante; Soares, Eduardo; Roudik, Peter; Rodriguez-Ferrand, Graciela|accessdate=2018-05-18}} 1) [[Pregnancy]] during the first 90 days (Art. 4) In order to practice the [[termination of pregnancy]] during the first 90 days, women whose situation is such that continuation of the pregnancy, childbirth, or motherhood would seriously compromise their physical or mental health, in view of their state of health, their economic, social, or family circumstances, the circumstances in which conception occurred, or the chance that the child would be born with abnormalities or malformations, shall apply to a public counselling center or to a fully authorized medical-social agency in the region, or to a [[physician]] of her choice. Art. 5 extend the explanation of family counselling centre when economic, social or family circumstances motivate the reasons to interrupt the pregnancy. 2) Pregnancy after the first 90 days (Art.6) Voluntary termination of pregnancy may be performed after the first 90 days when the [[pregnancy]] or childbirth is a serious threat to the woman’s life or when the pathological processes constitute a serious threat to the woman's physical or mental health, such as those associated with serious abnormalities or malformations of the fetus, have been diagnosed. Furthermore, there is the need for guardian's approval if a girl that is under 18 years old or the woman that is interdicted in order to carry out abortion (Art. 12 and Art. 14). Articles 18 and 19 cover the consequences for any person inducing a termination without the consent of the woman. ===Conscientious objection=== [[File:Geographical distribution of conscientious objectors in Italy.svg|thumb|upright=1.5|Geographical distribution of conscientious objectors in Italy
{{legend inline|#6f2c91|Italy}} {{legend inline|#a6ce39|North}} {{legend inline|#f7924b|Centre}} {{legend inline|#0b96c3|South}} {{legend inline|#e31a1c|Sicily and Sardinia}}]] [[File:Abortions per gynecologist in Italy.svg|thumb|upright=1.5|Abortions per gynecologist in Italy per working week in 2016 (data for Lombardia is of 2016)]] The law gives the option for [[health professional]]s to claim the right to refuse to perform abortion. If the health personnel demands to be [[conscientious objector]], they have to declare it in advance (Art.9). However, conscientious objection may not be invoked by health professionals if the personal intervention is essential in order to save the life of a woman in imminent danger. Italy keeps a record of the objecting doctors. According to data from the Ministry of Health, between 1997 and 2016 there was a 12.9% increase in the number of gynecologists who refuse to perform abortions on moral grounds, from 62.8% to 70.9%, the highest percentage ever recorded. As of 2016 the percentage is higher than the national average in [[Southern Italy]] (83.5%) and [[Insular Italy|Sicily and Sardinia]] (77.7%), and lower in [[Central Italy|Central]] (70.1%) and [[Northern Italy]] (63.9%). The percentage is growing in all the [[macroregion|macroregions]] except the North. As a result, voluntary abortion is performed only in 60% of the hospitals of the country. Also, non-objecting doctors suffers discrimination, and -in some provinces- needs to perform record-numbers of abortions, up to 15.8 per week in the [[province of Taranto]] ([[Apulia]]) or 12.2 in the [[province of Catania]] ([[Sicily]]).{{cite news |last1=Tamma |first1=Paola |title=Even where abortion is legal, access is not granted|url=https://www.europeandatajournalism.eu/eng/News/Data-news/Even-where-abortion-is-legal-access-is-not-granted |accessdate=22 August 2018 |work=VoxEurop/EDJNet |date=24 May 2018}} A resolution by the [[Council of Europe]] has found several violations of the [[European Social Charter]] in the situation: * [[right to health|right to protection of health]] (art. 11) of women seeking abortion; * [[right to work]] (art. 1) and to [[dignity]] at work (art. 26) of non-objecting medical practitioners, because of different treatment and moral harassment.{{cite web |title=Resolution CM/ResChS(2016)3 |url=https://search.coe.int/cm/Pages/result_details.aspx?ObjectId=0900001680687bdc |publisher=Council of Europe |accessdate=22 August 2018}}{{cite web |title=European Social Charter (Revised) |url=https://www.coe.int/en/web/conventions/full-list/-/conventions/rms/090000168007cf93 |publisher=Council of Europe |accessdate=22 August 2018}} ==See also== * [[Catholic Church and abortion]] ==Notes== {{reflist|refs= Standards for social protection of motherhood and on abortion, 194 Italy (1978) (Italian language).>}} ==References== {{commonscat}} *Spinelli, Angela, & Grandolfo, Michele. (2001). [https://web.archive.org/web/20060912044603/http://faculty.cua.edu/pennington/Law111/ItalyAbortion.htm Abortion in Italy]. ''Bollettino Epidemiologico Nazionale, 14 (4)''. Retrieved October 18, 2007. *"Abortion in Italy ." Ben Epicentro. 1 Apr. 2001. BEN-Notiziario ISS-Vol.14-n.4.

{{refimprove|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Ainslie Meares | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1910|3|3}} | birth_place = [[Malvern, Victoria]], [[Australia]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1986|9|19|1910|3|3}} | death_place = [[Melbourne]], Australia | occupation = Psychiatrist, hypnotherapist, psychotherapist, advocate of meditation | spouse = Bonnie, née Byrne (died 1979) | parents = Albert and Eva Meares | children = Russell, Garda, Sylvia }} '''Ainslie Dixon Meares''' (3 March 1910{{spaced ndash}}19 September 1986) was an [[Australian]] [[psychiatry|psychiatrist]], scholar of hypnotism, psychotherapist, authority on stress and a prolific author who lived and practised in [[Melbourne]].<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=i2spAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Y-YDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2704%2C4532118 "Obituary: Dr. Ainslie Meares, Cancer Victim's Guru",''The Sydney Morning Herald", (Monday, 22 September 1986), p.8].</ref>
==Early life== {{Hypnosis}} Ainslie Meares was born in [[Malvern, Victoria]], on 3 March 1910, the eldest son of medical practitioner Albert George Meares, (1875-1928),<ref>Albert's father, [[George Meares]] {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CMG}} (1825-1903) had been [[List of mayors and lord mayors of Melbourne#Mayors .281842.E2.80.931902.29|Lord Mayor of Melbourne]] from 1880 to 1881, and a [[Victorian Legislative Council|Member of the Victorian Legislative Council (MLC)]] from 1882 to 1886.</ref><ref>He died on 20 March 1928 ([http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/3919332 "Deaths", ''The Argus'', (Wednesday, 21 March 1928), p.1]).</ref><ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/179707914 "Large Estate: Former Melbourne Doctor", ''The (Brisbane) Telegraph'', (Saturday, 5 May 1928), p.9]; [http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/3952246 "Personal", ''The Argus'', (Saturday, 5 May 1928), p30].</ref> and Eva Gertrude Meares (1875-1926) (née Ham),<ref>Eva's father, [[Cornelius Ham|Cornelius Job Ham]] (1837-1909), had been [[List of mayors and lord mayors of Melbourne#Mayors .281842.E2.80.931902.29|Lord Mayor of Melbourne]] from 1881 to 1882, and a [[Victorian Legislative Council|Member of the Victorian Legislative Council (MLC)]] from 1882 to 1904.</ref><ref>She died on 30 June 1926 ([https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vLgUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8tcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6159%2C116445 "Deaths", ''The Age'', (Friday, 2 July 1926), p1]).</ref> who were married on 14 July 1903.<ref>"Weddings: Meares—Ham", ''The (Melbourne) Leader'', (Saturday, 25 July 1903), p.38].</ref> He married Bonnie Sylvia Byrne on 18 June 1934.<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/10947898 "Parchment and Ice-Blue: Meares—Byrne Wedding", ''The Argus'', (Tuesday, 19 June 1934), p.10].</ref>
Meares was educated at [[Melbourne Grammar School]], where he boxed and played tennis, at [[Trinity College (University of Melbourne)|Trinity College]],<ref>see ''The Fleur-de-Lys'' (1931-1934), passim.</ref> and at the [[University of Melbourne]], from which he graduated with a [[Bachelor of Science in Agriculture|Bachelor of Agricultural Science]] degree in 1934,<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/10920317 "University of Melbourne: Supplementary Examinations: February, 1934: Fourth Year Bachelor of Agricultural Science", ''The Argus'', (Wednesday, 21 March 1934), p.14].</ref> and a [[Bachelor of Medicine and Surgery]] degree in 1940.
Meares received his [[Psychiatrist|Diploma in Psychological Medicine]] from the University of Melbourne in September 1947,<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/22504612 "Conferring of Degrees: Diplomas", ''The Argus'', (Tuesday, 2 September 1947), p.15].</ref> and, on the basis of his presentation of a collection of 17 published papers relating to medical hypnotism (with each paper being independent of the others), he was awarded the higher degree of [[Doctor of Medicine#United Kingdom, Ireland and Commonwealth countries (excluding Canada)|Doctor of Medicine]] by the University of Melbourne in 1958.
Meares also served as a captain in the [[Royal Australian Army Medical Corps]] (1941–1945).<ref>[http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=A&veteranId=471771 Australian Army Service Record: Meares, Ainslie Dixon (VX64992)].</ref><ref>[https://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/NAAMedia/ViewPDF.aspx?B=6111455&D=D National Archives of Australia: Service Record: Meares, Ainslie Dixon (VX64992)].</ref>
Meares was a founding fellow of the [[Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists]] and, for a time, the president of the [[International Society for Clinical and Experimental Hypnosis]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bower|first1=H.|title=Obituary: Ainslie Dixon Meares|journal=Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry|volume=21, No. 2|issue=June, 1987|pages=251–2|doi=10.3109/00048678709160920}}</ref>
==Hypnotism== Meares was an internationally recognised expert in the medical uses of hypnotism<ref>Westmore (2012).</ref> and wrote a number of books describing his approach. His work may be divided into 3 periods: the hypnosis period, relief without drugs period and the stillness meditation period. These categories reflect the simplification and fine tuning of his method that occurred over time.<ref>Ainslie Meares on Meditation by Owen Bruhn. 2017</ref>
==Death== Meares died suddenly, of [[pneumonia]], in a Melbourne hospital on 19 September 1986.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=i2spAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Y-YDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2704%2C4532118 "Deaths", ''The Age'', (Monday, 22 September 1986), p.18].</ref> He was cremated.<ref>Westmore (2012).</ref> His wife, Bonnie, died on 27 December 1978. He was survived by their three children, Russell Meares (also a psychiatrist), Garda Meares Langley and Sylvia Meares Black.
== Publications == Meares was a prolific author, mainly on psychiatry, hypnotism, the treatment of cancer, and meditation. {{Main article|List of works by Ainslie Meares}}
==See also== * [[Atavistic regression]] * [[Health applications and clinical studies of meditation]] * [[Mind-body intervention]]
== Footnotes == {{Reflist|30em}}
==References== * [http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/206232715 Doctor's Dislike of Going to Court, ''The Age'', (Saturday, 20 May 1950), p.3.] * [http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/page/1734710 'Truth Drug' Evidence at Murder Trial: Brewer's 'Abnormal Love for His Mother', ''The Argus'', (Thursday, 21 September 1950), p.6.] * [http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/meares-ainslie-dixon-14944 Westmore, A., "Meares, Ainslie Dixon (1910—1986)", ''Australian Dictionary of Biography, Volume 18'', Melbourne University Press, (Melbourne) 2012]. * [http://www.trinity.unimelb.edu.au/media/docs/Fleur-de-Lys-1931-Oct-55aa070e-a200-4307-8705-21ea6dc4bc31-0.pdf ''The Fleur-de-Lys: A Magazine of Trinity College in the University of Melbourne'', Vol.3, No.31, (October 1931)]. * [http://trinity.unimelb.edu.au/media/docs/Fleur-de-Lys-1932-Oct-5f2ffec8-ac20-44d1-bae9-256bba7684d8-0.pdf ''The Fleur-de-Lys: A Magazine of Trinity College in the University of Melbourne'', Vol.3, No.32, (October 1932)]. * [http://trinity.unimelb.edu.au/media/docs/Fleur-de-Lys-1932-Oct-5f2ffec8-ac20-44d1-bae9-256bba7684d8-0.pdf ''The Fleur-de-Lys: A Magazine of Trinity College in the University of Melbourne'', Vol.3, No.33, (October 1933)]. * [http://trinity.unimelb.edu.au/media/docs/Fleur-de-Lys-1932-Oct-5f2ffec8-ac20-44d1-bae9-256bba7684d8-0.pdf ''The Fleur-de-Lys: A Magazine of Trinity College in the University of Melbourne'', Vol.3, No.34, (October 1934)]. * [https://yallambie.wordpress.com/2015/04 Telling Tales: Diggers in the Garden State, ''Yallambi'', 1 April 2015.]
== External links == * [http://findaid.library.uwa.edu.au/cgi-bin/nph-dweb/dynaweb/findaid/brett/@Generic__BookTextView/4103;cs=default;ts=default;pt=4345 Description of the source material gathered for book on Ainslie Meares by Lily Brett] (the book was never completed) * [http://handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/220078 Photograph of Meares] in his [[Spring Street, Melbourne|Spring Street]] consulting rooms, with [[St Patrick's Cathedral, Melbourne|St Patrick's Cathedral]] in the background

{{EngvarB|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} '''Blood donation in Bangladesh''' is an activity conducted by several different organisations. As of 2011, about 25% of the nation's blood supply came from voluntary donation, 20–25% from paid donors, and 50–55% from one-time donation for a specific patient.
==Background== [[Blood transfusion]] service became available in [[Bangladesh]] at the [[Dhaka Medical College and Hospital|Dhaka Medical College Hospital]] in 1950.<ref name=MBI>{{Cite journal | last1 = Islam | first1 = M. B. | title = Blood transfusion services in Bangladesh | doi = 10.4103/0973-6247.53880 | journal = Asian Journal of Transfusion Science | volume = 3 | issue = 2 | pages = 108–110 | year = 2009 | pmid = 20808657| pmc =2920470 }}</ref> Professional blood donors were the mainstay of blood donation in Bangladesh, with 47% of donated blood coming from professional donors as late as the year 2000.<ref name=MBI/> The potential for contamination in the supply, and the need for volunteer donors was well recognised.<ref name=MBI/> An estimate from 2011 is that of the 500,000 units of blood required annually, only 25% come from voluntary donation, 20–25% from paid donors, and 50–55% from one-time donation for a specific patient.<ref>{{cite news |author=Nurul Islam Hasib |date=14 June 2011 |title=Let Bangladeshi youth's blood 'flow' |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2011/06/14/speciallet-bangladeshi-youth-s-blood-flow |newspaper=bd24news.com}}</ref>
==SANDHANI== {{Main|Sandhani}} The first volunteer blood donation program in Bangladesh was begun in 1977 at [[Dhaka Medical College]], and was organized by [[SANDHANI]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sandhani.org/about-us/history/ |title=Sandhani, official web site, history}}</ref>. SANDHANI has now 24 units in different medical and dental colleges.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sandhani.org/contact-us/ |title=Sandhani, official web site, contacts}}</ref> SANDHANI is a voluntary institution run by the medical and dental students of BANGLADESH. It is mainly working on motivation on voluntary blood donation and posthumous eye donation in Bangladesh. SANDHANI is also working for the helpless patient in the community by serving them with drug from the drug bank, donating blood to the thalassaemia patient, giving relief to the flooded and disaster affected people etc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sandhani.org/home/ |title=Sandhani, official web site, home}}</ref>
==Medicine Club== {{Main|Medicine Club}} Medicine Club is also a Non-profit Humanitarian Organization in Bangladesh volunteered by Medical & Dental students<ref>http://medicineclub-bd.org/about-us/</ref>. The organization was founded on January 31, 1981 at [[Mymensingh Medical College]]<ref>http://medicineclub-bd.org/about-us/</ref> with the intention of helping the helpless and serving humanity. Now it has 21 Units in different Medical & dental colleges.<ref>http://medicineclub-bd.org/about-us/</ref> It has since broadened its scope to include voluntary blood donating, prevent Thalassaemia <ref>http://medicineclub-bd.org/thalassaemia/</ref> throughout Bangladesh & rise awareness about this. It contributes a large amount of donated blood throughout Bangladesh<ref>http://medicineclub-bd.org/blood-division/</ref>. It also helps poor patients by donating money and drugs<ref>http://medicineclub-bd.org/drug-division/</ref>. This organization also distributes vaccines<ref>http://medicineclub-bd.org/vaccination-division/</ref> & warm cloths<ref>http://medicineclub-bd.org/warm-clothes-distribution/</ref> and arranges "Health Check Up Campaigns"<ref>http://medicineclub-bd.org/health-check-up/</ref>.
==Red Crescent Society== {{Main|Bangladesh Red Crescent Society}} The [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement]] began a blood program in Bangladesh in 1981.<ref name=RC>{{cite web |url=http://www.bdrcs.org/programs-and-projects/blood |title=Bangladesh Red Crescent Society: Blood Program}}</ref> Today they operate several centres, using both whole blood and fractionated blood components.<ref name=RC/>
==Badhan== A 1997 survey of students at the [[University of Dhaka]] had found a generally favourable attitude towards voluntary blood donation, and an overwhelmingly unfavourable attitude to paid blood donation, and recommended that a campaign should be started immediately to increase awareness and participation in voluntary blood donation among the student population.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Hosain, G.M.M. |author2=Anisuzzaman, M. |author3=Begum, A. |year=1997|title=Knowledge and attitude towards voluntary blood donation among Dhaka University students in Bangladesh|journal=East African Medical Journal|volume=74|issue=9|pages=549–553|pmid=9487428}}</ref>
Badhan is a non-political voluntary [[blood donation|blood donors']] organisation in Bangladesh that was established in 1997.<ref name=badhan>{{cite news |author=Mahmud-Ur-Rashid |date=1 February 2007 |title=Campus Spotlight: Badhan |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/campus/2007/02/01/camspotlight_BADHAN.htm |work=Star Campus |publisher=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]]}}</ref> Badhan's first activity was a free blood-group testing program that took place on 24 October 1997 at [[Shahidullah Hall]] of the University of Dhaka.<ref name=badhan/> Shahidullah Hall is very close to Dhaka Medical College and Hospital, and before that time people needing blood for patients would gather regularly in or near the hall gate, seeking help.<ref name=badhan/> Mohammad Shahidul Islam Ripon was the principal originator of the program, along with other students.<ref name=website/>
The blood provided is fresh rather than stored,<ref name=website>{{cite web |url=http://badhan.org |title=BADHAN (A Voluntary Blood Donor's Organization): Official Web Site |accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref> using a database of people whose blood type has been previously established. The graduate- and postgraduate-level students of Bangladeshi universities and postgraduate colleges are the main participants of the organisation.<ref name=badhan/> The organisation is active in 14 universities and 29 university colleges.<ref name=website/>
Other activities include raising awareness about donating fresh blood, donating blood voluntarily for patients and helping poor people in time of natural disasters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.du.ac.bd/main_menu/co_curricular |title=Co-curricular activities |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160210131500/http://www.du.ac.bd/main_menu/co_curricular |archivedate=10 February 2016 |accessdate=10 February 2016 }}</ref>
Financing comes primarily from individual members and ex-members, as well as from the universities and colleges administration, from donations.<ref name=website/> The California non-profit organisation SpaandanB has been a significant contributor from outside Bangladesh.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spaandanb.org/projects/badhan/badhan1.html#3|title=SpaandanB project: Badhan Blood Transfusion Centre}}</ref> Badhan wants to make blood donation as a social movement. It's ultimate goals are (a) none should die from lack of blood, (b) every person knows his/her blood group. Head office of Badhan is located at ground floor of TSC, Dhaka University.
==Bangladesh Blood Services== {{Main|Bangladesh Blood Services}} The Bangladesh Blood Services is organized volunteer blood donation program in [[Bangladesh]] was begun in 2017.<ref name=BBS>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbs.indobangla24.com |title=Bangladesh Blood Services: ABOUT BBS}}</ref> Bangladesh Blood Services operates [[Bangladesh|Bangladesh]]’s blood supply in a manner that gains the trust, commitment and confidence of all [[Bangladesh|Bangladeshi]] by providing a safe, secure, cost-effective, affordable and accessible supply of quality blood, blood products and their alternatives.
==See also== * {{portal-inline|Bangladesh}} * {{portal-inline|Medicine}}
==References== [http://www.badhan.org]{{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.orcabloodforlife.org OCRA: Blood for Life (Old Rajshahi Cadets Association)] * [http://quantummethod.org/node/673#bd Quantum Method: History of Blood donation in Bangladesh] * [http://www.blooddonorsbd.com Blood Donors Club, Bangladesh: A Community of Voluntary Blood Donors of Bangladesh]
[[Category:Health in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Blood donation]]

{{distinguish|text=the Center for Medical Progress at the [[Manhattan Institute for Policy Research]]}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Center for Medical Progress |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |motto = |formation = March 7, 2013<ref>{{cite web |title= The Center for Medical Progress |work= Business Search - Business Entities |publisher= California Secretary of State's Office |accessdate= September 2, 2015 |url= http://kepler.sos.ca.gov/ |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150315010639/http://kepler.sos.ca.gov/# |archive-date= March 15, 2015 |dead-url= yes |df= mdy-all }}</ref> |status = [[501(c)(3)]] |purpose = |headquarters = [[Irvine, California]] |region_served= |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |budget = |budget_year = |revenue = |revenue_year = |disbursements = |expenses = |expenses_year = |endowment = |staff = |staff_year = |volunteers = |volunteers_year = |slogan = |mission = |tax_id = 46-2252984<ref name= selectcheck>{{cite web |title= Exempt Organizations Select Check |work= Internal Revenue Service |accessdate= September 2, 2015 |url= https://apps.irs.gov/app/eos/pub78Search.do;jsessionid=iFRu+6fwM-dYG3l5y-Mk0Q__?ein1=&names=Center+for+Medical+Progress&city=Irvine&state=CA&country=US&deductibility=all&dispatchMethod=searchCharities&submitName=Search }}</ref> |website = [http://www.centerformedicalprogress.org CenterforMedicalProgress.org] }}
The '''Center for Medical Progress''' ('''CMP''') is an [[anti-abortion]] organization <!-- Described this way by Reuters, Associated Press and FoxNews.com - see talk before changing--> founded by [[David Daleiden]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mediamatters.org/blog/2015/12/17/misinformer-of-the-year-the-center-for-medical/207506|title=Misinformer Of The Year: The Center For Medical Progress|date=December 15, 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2015/07/15/live_action_distributed_the_planned_parenthood_sting_video_why_aren_t_they.html|title=What Is the Center for Medical Progress, the Group Behind the Latest Viral Abortion Video?|first=Amanda|last=Marcotte|date=July 15, 2015|publisher=|via=Slate}}</ref><ref name=nyt23jul/><ref name=yahoohealthjul/><ref name=opresc>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/07/21/planned-parenthood-official-jokes-about-buying-lamborghini-with-fetus-tissue-profits.html|title=Hoaxers Fail to Nail Planned Parenthood in New Video|work=The Daily Beast|quote=Operation Rescue provides “advice, consulting, funds” to the CMP}}</ref><ref name=nation/> The CMP is best known for producing undercover recordings that prompted [[Planned Parenthood 2015 undercover videos controversy|a controversy over Planned Parenthood in 2015]]; CMP established a fake company to pose as buyers of fetal tissue and secretly recording Planned Parenthood officials during meetings.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/07/22/425314909/sting-videos-part-of-longtime-campaign-against-planned-parenthood|title=Sting Videos Part Of Longtime Campaign Against Planned Parenthood|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="washingtonpost.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/meet-the-millennial-who-infiltrated-the-guarded-world-of-abortion-providers/2015/10/14/25aaf862-678b-11e5-9223-70cb36460919_story.html|title=Meet the millennial who infiltrated the guarded world of abortion providers|website=Washington Post}}</ref>
The CMP released edited videos of the discussions which made it appear as if Planned Parenthood intended to profit from fetal tissue, although the full unedited videos instead showed that Planned Parenthood requested only a fee to cover costs without any profit.<ref name="factcheck"/> A [[grand jury]] in [[Harris County, Texas]] took no action against Planned Parenthood, but instead indicted Daleiden and a second CMP employee on felony charges of tampering with governmental records and attempting to purchase human organs.<ref name="indicted"/> The charges were dropped six months later, but in March 2017 Daleiden and the second CMP employee were charged with 15 felonies in California—one for each of the people whom they had filmed without consent, and one for [[criminal conspiracy]] to invade privacy.
The videos led conservative politicians to request a criminal investigation of [[Planned Parenthood]] for selling fetal tissue, and in December 2017 the [[United States Department of Justice|US Department of Justice]] revealed that it was investigating Planned Parenthood.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/12/07/planned-parenthood-under-investigation-by-justice-department-over-sale-fetal-tissue.html|title=Planned Parenthood under investigation by Justice Department over sale of fetal tissue|date=December 7, 2017|publisher=[[Fox News]]|first=Brooke|last=Singman}}</ref>
==Organization== [[David Daleiden]] formed the Center for Medical Progress in 2013 after working for [[Live Action (organization)|Live Action]] for five years. He was that organization’s director of research "during the early stages" of the project to make secret recordings of [[Planned Parenthood]] clinics.<ref name=maker>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/07/15/who-made-the-planned-parenthood-video.html|title=Maker of Planned Parenthood Video Called Abortion 'Genocide'|work=The Daily Beast|date=July 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name=more>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/planned-parenthood-sting-video_55ad3b63e4b0caf721b3633d|title=Planned Parenthood: More Sting Videos Are Coming|work=The Huffington Post|quote=The CMP was founded by David Daleiden, an anti-abortion activist who previously worked for the group Live Action, known for its heavily edited undercover videos of Planned Parenthood staffers.}}</ref> The CMP's board members include Daleiden, [[Troy Newman (activist)|Troy Newman]], and [[Albin Rhomberg]],<ref name=nation/> and they receive advice, consulting and funds from [[Operation Rescue (Kansas)|Operation Rescue]].<ref name=nail/> Their website initially described the organization as "dedicated to informing and educating both the lay public and the scientific community about the latest advances in regenerative medicine, cell-based therapies, and related disciplines."<ref name=nyt23jul/> It was initially registered by Daleiden as a tax-exempt biomedicine charity,<ref name=sting>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/planned-parenthood-sting-video_55a92205e4b0896514d11ac9|title=Group Behind Planned Parenthood Sting Video May Have Tricked IRS, Donors|date=July 17, 2015|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref> but after questions about the group's tax exempt status the organization's stated mission was changed to "a group of citizen journalists dedicated to monitoring and reporting on medical ethics and advances."<ref name=nyt23jul/>
==Undercover videos controversy== {{main|Planned Parenthood 2015 undercover videos controversy}}
Daleiden's organization set up a fake biomedical research company, called Biomax Procurement Services. Under this guise, they posed as potential buyers of aborted fetal tissue and organs, and secretly recorded [[Planned Parenthood]] officials during meetings.<ref name=cover>{{cite web|title=Sting Videos Part Of Longtime Campaign Against Planned Parenthood|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/07/22/425314909/sting-videos-part-of-longtime-campaign-against-planned-parenthood|publisher=NPR.org|accessdate=2016-09-28}}</ref> CMP released edited versions of these videos, which it promoted as showing Planned Parenthood officials "price haggling over ‘baby parts'".<ref name=second/> When the full, unedited, videos became available, they instead showed "a Planned Parenthood executive repeatedly saying its clinics want to cover their costs, not make money, when donating fetal tissue from abortions for scientific research."<ref name="factcheck"/> According to the lawyer for Planned Parenthood, Roger K. Evans, Biomax proposed “sham procurement contracts,” offering {{USD}}1,600 for liver and thymus fetal tissues.<ref>{{cite news|title=Planned Parenthood Tells Congress More Videos of Clinics Might Surface|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/21/us/planned-parenthood-tells-congress-more-videos-of-clinics-might-surface.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref>
The videos and allegations attracted widespread media coverage, and re-invigorated the long-term American political [[abortion rights|abortion debate]].<ref name=NYT4>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/07/20/us/politics/ap-us-congress-planned-parenthood.html|title=Planned Parenthood Says Video Part of Decadelong Harassment|work=The New York Times|date=July 20, 2015|accessdate=August 7, 2015|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> Five separate [[United States Congress|congressional]] investigations of Planned Parenthood were launched as a result of the videos.<ref>Molly Redden, [https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/jan/25/planned-parenthood-grand-jury-indicts-anti-abortion-activists Grand jury investigating Planned Parenthood indicts anti-abortion activists instead], ''The Guardian'' (January 25, 2016).</ref> A bill to defund Planned Parenthood was proposed, but failed to pass in the Senate on August 3, 2015.<ref name=reuters08032015>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/08/03/us-usa-plannedparenthood-idUSKCN0Q80DL20150803 "Senate blocks Planned Parenthood defunding measure"], Reuters, August 3, 2015.</ref> Several states cut contracts and funding for Planned Parenthood following the videos, regardless of whether Planned Parenthood provided abortion services in those states.<ref name="nyt-la">{{cite news|work=The New York Times|date=September 1, 2015|title=Louisiana Lays Bare Difficulty in Push to Cut Planned Parenthood Funding|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/02/us/politics/louisiana-lays-bare-difficulty-in-push-to-cut-planned-parenthood-funding.html|first=Jackie|last=Calmes}}</ref> An editorial in ''[[The New England Journal of Medicine]]'' was highly critical of the Center for Medical Progress, describing the videos as part of a "campaign of misinformation" by an organization that "twist(s) the facts."<ref name="nejm">{{cite journal|vauthors=Topulos GP, Greene MF, Drazen JM|title=Planned Parenthood at Risk|journal=N. Engl. J. Med.|volume=373|page=963|year=2015|pmid=26267451|doi=10.1056/NEJMe1510281|url=http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMe1510281}}</ref>
[[TeleSUR]] television network listed The Center for Medical Progress as one of "The 7 Biggest Bigots of 2015" for "attacking women's rights in the United States."<ref name=Mallett-Outtrim >{{citation |last= Mallett-Outtrim |first=Ryan |date=December 17, 2015 |title= The 7 Biggest Bigots of 2015 |publisher= [[TeleSUR]] |url= http://www.telesurtv.net/english/analysis/The-7-Biggest-Bigots-of-2015-20151217-0043.html |accessdate= December 17, 2015}}</ref>
[[Media Matters for America]] named The Center for Medical Progress their "Misinformer Of The Year" for 2015.<ref>{{citation|title=Misinformer Of The Year: The Center For Medical Progress|accessdate=April 11, 2016|last=Kittel|first=Olivia|url=http://mediamatters.org/blog/2015/12/17/misinformer-of-the-year-the-center-for-medical/207506}}</ref>
===Civil lawsuits against the CMP=== In the aftermath of the videos being released, the [[National Abortion Federation]] sued the Center for Medical Progress.<ref>[http://rhrealitycheck.org/article/2015/07/31/national-abortion-federation-files-lawsuit-planned-parenthood-attack-group/ National Abortion Federation Files Lawsuit Against Planned Parenthood Attack Group], RH Reality Check, July 31, 2015</ref><ref>[http://www.newsweek.com/planned-parenthood-lawsuit-legal-threat-364833 Planned Parenthood Weighs Response to Undercover Videos], ''[[Newsweek]]'', August 21, 2015</ref> In September 2015, two courts ruled that Daleiden and the Center for Medical Progress must turn over private documents and submit to depositions about how they orchestrated their video sting, and could require Daleiden to turn over paperwork and details of the operation, and provide the full raw footage he collected while posing as an executive of the fictitious tissue procurement firm Biomax.<ref>{{cite web|title=Courts rule Daleiden must turn over documents, video footage|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/09/david-daleiden-center-for-medical-progress-planned-parenthood-video-213992|publisher=[[Politico]]|accessdate=September 23, 2015}}</ref> On December 4, 2015, U.S. Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy denied an emergency appeal from the Center for Medical Progress to block the lower courts' order that would require CMP to release the names of its donors.<ref name="Newsweek_12_5_2015">{{cite web|author=Martinez, J.|date=December 5, 2015|title=Supreme Court Weighing In on Planned Parenthood Videos|url=http://www.newsweek.com/supreme-court-planned-parenthood-videos-401597|accessdate=December 6, 2015}}</ref>
On January 15, 2016, Planned Parenthood commenced a lawsuit in [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|federal district court in San Francisco]] against the CMP, alleging that the group and its members, in setting up a fake tissue procurement company and using fake identities to set up private meetings engaged in [[wire fraud|wire]] and [[mail fraud]] in violation of the [[Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act]] (RICO Act), unlawfully [[invasion of privacy|invaded privacy]], and engaged in illegal secret recording, and [[trespassing]].<ref>Chris Frates, [http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/14/politics/planned-parenthood-lawsuit-center-for-medical-progress/ Planned Parenthood files suit against anti-abortion videos group], CNN (January 15, 2016).</ref><ref>Nathan Pemberton, [http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/01/pp-files-lawsuit-over-secretly-filmed-videos.html Planned Parenthood Files Lawsuit Over Secretly Filmed Videos], ''Daily Intelligencer'' (January 14, 2016).</ref>
===Criminal proceedings=== On January 25, 2016, the findings of a [[Harris County, Texas]], [[grand jury]] investigating the affair were made public. The grand jury cleared Planned Parenthood of any wrongdoing, and indicted two CMP employees. David Daleiden was indicted on one felony charge of tampering with a governmental record by making a fake driver's license and one [[misdemeanor]] count related to purchasing human organs; another center employee, Sandra Merritt, was indicted on one charge of tampering with a governmental record.<ref name="indicted">{{cite news|first=Manny|last=Fernandez|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/26/us/2-abortion-foes-behind-planned-parenthood-videos-are-indicted.html|title=2 Abortion Foes Behind Planned Parenthood Videos Are Indicted|work=New York Times|date=January 25, 2016}}</ref> The Texas charges against Daleiden and Merritt, however, were eventually dropped due to questions surrounding the authority of the grand jury to indict Daleiden and Merritt, due to the extension of the grand jury's term, with District Attorney Devon Anderson stating "The grand jury took the investigation where the facts led it; however, Texas law limits what can be investigated after a grand jury extension order is issued. In light of this and after careful research and review, this office dismissed the indictments."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/27/us/last-charges-dropped-against-abortion-opponents-in-planned-parenthood-case.html|title=Last Charges Dropped Against Abortion Foes in Making of Planned Parenthood Video|first=Manny|last=Fernandez|date=July 26, 2016|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/last-charges-against-duo-in-planned-parenthood-video-sting-are-dropped/2016/07/26/ff0792f6-5352-11e6-bbf5-957ad17b4385_story.html|title=Last charges against duo in Planned Parenthood video sting are dropped|website=Washington Post}}</ref>
On June 13, 2016, a Texas judge dismissed the misdemeanor charge of purchase and sale of human organs due to a technicality in the Harris County prosecutor's indictment. The next day, the Harris County District Attorney's Office said it would not fight the decision. The prosecution failed to provide proof that any fees offered or paid for aborted fetal parts were not covered by exceptions like physician or transport fees. The hearing for the felony charge was July 26, 2016.<ref>Perry Chiaramonte, [http://www.foxnews.com/us/2016/06/14/key-charge-dropped-against-pro-life-activist-in-planned-parenthood-sting.html Key Charge Dropped Against Pro Life Activist in Planned Parenthood Sting], FOX News (June 14, 2016)</ref>
On March 28, 2017, Daleiden and Merritt were charged with 15 felonies in the State of California - one for each of the people whom they had filmed without consent, and one for criminal conspiracy to invade privacy.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dalton|first1=Andrew|title=Undercover videos of fetal tissue talks spur felony charges|url=http://www.timescolonist.com/undercover-videos-of-fetal-tissue-talks-spur-felony-charges-1.13281156|work=Times Colonist|agency=AP|date=March 28, 2017}}</ref> None of the felony charges include fraud.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-planned-parenthood-charges-activists-20170328-story.html|title=Two antiabortion activists behind undercover Planned Parenthood videos charged with 15 felonies|first=Matt|last=Hamilton|date=March 28, 2017|publisher=|via=LA Times}}</ref> Daleiden's attorney, Steve Cooley, has sought the dismissal of all charges, based on the fact that the accusers are not named in the indictment, which would prevent Daleiden and Merritt from confronting their accusers, in violation of their [[Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Sixth Amendment]] rights.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-plannedparenthood-california-idUSKBN1800AW|title=Anti-abortion activists seek dismissal of California privacy case|date=May 4, 2017|publisher=|via=Reuters}}</ref>
On 21 June 2017, fourteen of the charges were dismissed, with leave to amend, on the grounds that they were legally insufficient.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Egelko|first1=Bob|title=SF judge deals setback to prosecutors in abortion sting videos|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/SF-judge-deals-setback-to-prosecutors-in-abortion-11237776.php|accessdate=22 June 2017|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=21 June 2017}}</ref> "Leave to amend" means that the prosecutors were allowed the option to re-file the charges with more details; the prosecutors did so some time during the week of July 3, and all fifteen felony charges against Daleiden and Merritt are active again.<ref>http://m.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/California-files-more-charges-against-11271723.php#photo-13200872</ref>
