{{Infobox company | name = The Doctors Company | type = Member-owned interinsurance exchange | foundation = April 15, 1976 | location_city = [[Napa County, California]] (Napa mailing address) | location_country = United States | industry = Property and casualty insurance | homepage = {{URL |www.thedoctors.com}} }}
'''The Doctors Company''' is a [[medical malpractice]] insurance company headquartered outside [[Napa, California]], USA.
==Description== The Doctors Company claims to be the largest physician-owned medical malpractice insurer in the U.S, with 79,000 insureds nationwide, $4 billion in assets, $1.9 billion in member surplus, and a financial strength rating of A from [[A. M. Best]] and [[Fitch Group|Fitch Ratings]] in fiscal year 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedoctors.com/ecm/groups/public/@tdc/@web/documents/document/con_id_013330.pdf|title=2016 Financial Facts|last=|first=|date=June 2017|website=|publisher=The Doctors Company|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=November 17, 2017}}</ref>
Founded in 1976, The Doctors Company operates as a member-owned interinsurance exchange, with a number of wholly owned subsidiaries, and is led by a 14-member Board of Governors.
In 2008, The Doctors Company merged with Los Angeles-based [[SCPIE Holdings, Inc]].<ref>{{Cite news |title= Merger lets Doctors cut malpractice-insurance rates |work= San Francisco Business Times |author= Chris Rauber |date= September 14, 2008 |url= http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2008/09/15/newscolumn3.html |accessdate= September 17, 2011 }}</ref> In October 2010, the company completed a $386 million purchase of American Physicians Capital, Inc.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Doctors Co. buys American Physicians Capital for $386M |work= San Francisco Business Times |date=October 25, 2010 |url= http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/news/2010/10/25/doctors-co-acquires-formerly-public.html |accessdate= September 17, 2011 }}</ref> On October 19, 2011, The Doctors Company acquired FPIC Insurance Group, Inc., and its subsidiaries First Professionals Insurance Company, Inc.; Advocate, MD Insurance of the Southwest, Inc.; Anesthesiologists Professional Assurance Company; and Intermed Insurance Company.<ref>{{Cite news |title= The Doctors Co. Completes Acquisition of FPIC |work= Insurance Journal |date= October 20, 2011 |url= http://www.insurancejournal.com/news/national/2011/10/20/220951.htm |accessdate= October 26, 2011 }}</ref>
== Tribute Plan == In 2007, The Doctors Company launched a retirement benefit for members called the Tribute Plan. The plan’s purpose is to reward members for loyalty to the company and for providing outstanding patient care. The company sets aside funds for eligible members, and those members receive a financial award when they meet plan criteria upon retirement from the practice of medicine.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Medical Malpractice Insurer to Fund Retirement Package |work= San Francisco Business Times |author= Chris Rauber |date= May 6, 2007 |url= http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2007/05/07/story15.html |accessdate= September 17, 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.thedoctors.com/Join/Rewards/CON_ID_002923 Tribute Plan Summary, The Doctors Company]</ref>

page.title: The International Network of Cholesterol Skeptics

revision.text:
{{update|date=October 2017}} '''The International Network of Cholesterol Skeptics''' (or '''THINCS''') is a group of scientists, physicians, and other academicians from around the world who dispute the widely accepted [[lipid hypothesis]] of [[atherosclerosis]]. THINCS was founded in January 2003, and its founder and current spokesman is [[Uffe Ravnskov]]. ==Cholesterol controversy== {{main|Saturated fat and cardiovascular disease}} Since the 1950s, the lipid hypothesis (also known as the "Diet-Heart Idea"), which posits that [[saturated fat]] and high [[cholesterol]] play a role in the causation of [[atherosclerosis]] and [[cardiovascular disease]], has gained general acceptance in the medical and scientific communities. Currently, there is [[scientific consensus]] that the lipid hypothesis has been validated.{{cite journal |author=Steinberg D |title=Thematic review series: the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. An interpretive history of the cholesterol controversy, part V: the discovery of the statins and the end of the controversy |journal=J. Lipid Res. |volume=47 |issue=7 |pages=1339–51 |year=2006 |pmid=16585781 |doi=10.1194/jlr.R600009-JLR200}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Brook J, Rifkind B |title=Cholesterol and coronary heart disease prevention--a transatlantic consensus |journal=Eur. Heart J. |volume=10 |issue=8 |pages=702–11 |year=1989 |pmid=2676536}}{{cite journal |author= |title=Consensus conference. Lowering blood cholesterol to prevent heart disease |journal=JAMA |volume=253 |issue=14 |pages=2080–6 |year=1985 |pmid=3974099|doi=10.1001/jama.253.14.2080}} For example, in 1984, a [[National Institutes of Health]] consensus development conference found that: {{Quotation|It has been established beyond a reasonable doubt that lowering definitely elevated blood cholesterol levels (specifically, blood levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol) will reduce the risk of heart attacks caused by [[coronary artery disease|coronary heart disease]].}} The success of [[hypolipidemic agent|cholesterol-lowering medication]] such as [[statin]]s in preventing heart attacks has been seen as further validation of the lipid hypothesis. THINCS members dispute this consensus and assert that the lipid hypothesis is not adequately proven by the evidence. They point to a number of studies which, in their view, either contradict the lipid hypothesis or show it to be inconclusive. The THINCS website front page stated in June 2008: {{Quotation|For decades, enormous human and financial resources have been wasted on the cholesterol campaign, more promising research areas have been neglected, producers and manufacturers of animal food all over the world have suffered economically, and millions of healthy people have been frightened and badgered into eating a tedious and flavorless diet or into taking potentially dangerous drugs for the rest of their lives. As the scientific evidence in support of the cholesterol campaign is non-existent, we consider it important to stop it as soon as possible.[http://www.thincs.org/ Thincs - The International network of cholesterol skeptics]. Accessed: 2008-06-15. (Archived by WebCite at https://www.webcitation.org/5Yd5qUv4j)}} The members of THINCS have various differing hypotheses on the actual causes of heart disease, but all agree however in rejecting the lipid hypothesis, which they claim has repeatedly failed to be validated by scientific testing and research.[http://www.thincs.org www.thincs.org], main page. Accessed: 21 January 2007. ==Criticism== [[Harriet Hall]] in the ''[[Skeptical Inquirer]]'' has noted:
There is the International Network of Cholesterol Skeptics (THINCS), a group that disputes the role of cholesterol in cardiovascular disease. They are led by Uffe Ravnskov, author of ''The Cholesterol Myths'', and Malcolm Kendrick, author of ''The Great Cholesterol Con''. They cherry-pick the scientific literature to find studies that support their theses, ignore the flaws in those studies, and ignore the vast body of literature that contradicts them.Hall, Harriet. (2017). [https://www.csicop.org/si/show/statin_denialism "Statin Denialism"]. ''[[Skeptical Inquirer]]''. Retrieved November 28, 2018.
==See also== * [[AIM-HIGH trial]] minimal effect of increasing HDL * [[Lipid hypothesis]] the assertion that [[cholesterol]] LDL is "bad" HDL is "good" for preventing [[coronary artery disease]] * [[Obesity]] & [[Overweight]] effects of excess body fat on heart & blood vessels *[[Saturated fat and cardiovascular disease]] internationally [[Medical ethics|orthodox]] medical advice ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * [[Uffe Ravnskov]], ''The Cholesterol Myths: Exposing the Fallacy that Saturated Fat and Cholesterol Cause Heart Disease'' (2000), {{ISBN|0-9670897-0-0}}, {{ISBN|978-0-9670897-0-6}}. * [[Malcolm Kendrick]], ''The Great Cholesterol Con: The Truth About What Really Causes Heart Disease and How to Avoid It'' (2007), {{ISBN|1-84454-360-9}}, {{ISBN|978-1-84454-360-1}}. ==External links== *{{Official website|www.thincs.org}} *[http://www.spiked-online.com/newsite/article/548#.W0YfooWAHs0 The Great Cholesterol Myth] - Online essay *[http://nhlbisupport.com/chd1/chdexp.htm Coronary Heart Disease Explained], from the [[National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute]] {{DEFAULTSORT:International Network of Cholesterol Skeptics}} [[Category:International medical and health organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2003]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=August 2016}} {{technical|date=January 2015}} }} [[File:BRAM-COR-VAPOR-COMPRESSION-DISTILLER.jpg|thumb|Vapor compression distiller made by BRAM-COR (Italy)]] '''Vapor-compression evaporation''' is the [[evaporation]] method by which a [[Centrifugal fan|blower]], [[gas compressor|compressor]] or jet ejector is used to [[Gas compression|compress]], and thus, increase the pressure of the vapor produced. Since the pressure increase of the vapor also generates an increase in the [[condensation]] temperature, the same vapor can serve as the heating medium for its "mother" liquid or solution being concentrated, from which the vapor was generated to begin with. If no compression was provided, the vapor would be at the same temperature as the boiling liquid/solution, and no [[heat transfer]] could take place. It is also sometimes called ''vapor compression distillation (VCD)''. If compression is performed by a mechanically driven compressor or blower, this evaporation process is usually referred to as '''MVR''' (mechanical vapor recompression). In case of compression performed by high pressure motive [[steam]] [[injector|ejectors]], the process is usually called '''thermocompression''' or '''steam compression'''. ==MVR process== ===Energy input=== In this case the energy input to the system lies in the pumping energy of the compressor. The theoretical energy consumption will be equal to E=Q*(H2-H1), where * E is the total theoretical pumping energy * Q is the mass of vapors passing through the compressor * H1, H2 are the total heat content of unit mass of vapors, respectively upstream and downstream the compressor. In [[SI]] units, these are respectively measured in [[Joule|kJ]], [[kg]] and kJ/kg. The actual energy input will be greater than the theoretical value and will depend on the efficiency of the system, which is usually between 30% and 60%. For example, suppose the theoretical energy input is 300 kJ and the efficiency is 30%. The actual energy input would be 300 x 100/30 = 1,000 kJ. In a large unit, the compression power is between 35 and 45 [[kW]] per metric ton of compressed vapors.{{clarify|date=January 2015}} ===Equipment for MVR evaporators=== The compressor is necessarily the core of the unit. Compressors used for this application are usually of the [[centrifugal compressor|centrifugal]] type, or [[positive displacement pump|positive displacement]] units such as the [[Roots blower]]s, similar to the (much smaller) [[Roots type supercharger]]. Very large units (evaporation capacity 100 metric tons per hour or more) sometimes use [[Axial-flow compressor]]s. The compression work will deliver the steam [[superheated steam|superheated]] if compared to the theoretical pressure/temperature equilibrium. For this reason, the vast majority of MVR units feature a [[superheating|desuperheater]] between the compressor and the main heat exchanger. ==Thermocompression== ===Energy input=== The energy input is here given by the energy of a quantity of steam ('''motive steam'''), at a pressure higher than those of both the inlet and the outlet vapors. The quantity of compressed vapors is therefore higher than the inlet : Qd = Qs + Qm
Where Qd is the steam quantity at ejector delivery, Qs at ejector suction and Qm is the motive steam quantity. For this reason, a thermocompression evaporator often features a vapor [[Condenser (heat transfer)|condenser]], due to the possible excess of steam necessary for the compression if compared with the steam required to evaporate the solution. The quantity Qm of motive steam per unit suction quantity is a function of both the ''motive ratio'' of motive steam pressure vs. suction pressure and the [[compression ratio]] of delivery pressure vs. suction pressure. In principle, the higher the compression ratio and the lower the motive ratio the higher will be the specific motive steam consumption, i. e. the less efficient the energy balance. ===Thermocompression equipment=== The heart of any thermocompression evaporator is clearly the [[injector|steam ejector]], exhaustively described in the relevant page. The size of the other pieces of equipment, such as the main [[heat exchanger]], the [[vapor head]], etc. (see [[evaporator]] for details), is governed by the evaporation process. ==Comparison== These two compression-type evaporators have different fields of application, although they do sometimes overlap. * An MVR unit will be preferable for a large unit, thanks to the reduced energy consumption. The largest single body MVR evaporator built (1968, by Whiting Co., later Swenson Evaporator Co., Harvey, Ill. in [[Cirò Marina]], [[Italy]]) was a [[sodium chloride|salt]] [[crystallizer]], evaporating approximately 400 metric tons per hour of water, featuring an axial-flow compressor (Brown Boveri, later ABB). This unit was transformed around 1990 to become the first effect of a [[multiple effect evaporator]]. MVR evaporators with 10 tons or more evaporating capacity are common. * The compression ratio in a MVR unit does not usually exceed 1.8. At a compression ratio of 1.8, if the evaporation is performed at atmospheric pressure (0.101 [[MPa]]), the condensation pressure after compression will be 0.101 x 1.8 = 0.1818 [MPa]. At this pressure, the condensation temperature of the water vapor at the heat exchanger will be 390 [[Kelvin|K]]. Taking into account the [[boiling point elevation]] of the salt water we wish to evaporate (8 K for a saturated salt solution), this leaves a temperature difference of less than 8 K at the heat exchanger. A small ∆T leads to slow heat transfer, meaning that we will need a very large heating surface to transfer the required heat. Axial-flow and Roots compressor may reach slightly higher compression ratios. * Thermocompression evaporators may reach higher compression ratios - at a cost. A compression ratio of 2 is possible (and sometimes more) but unless the motive steam is at a reasonably high pressure (say, 16 [[bar (unit)|bar]] g - 250 [[psig]] - or more), the motive steam consumption will be in the range of 2 kg per kg of suction vapors. A higher compression ratio means a smaller heat exchanger, and a reduced investment cost. Moreover, a compressor is an expensive machine, while an ejector is much simpler and cheap. As a conclusion, MVR machines are used in large, energy-efficient units, while thermocompression units tend to limit their use to small units, where energy consumption is not a big issue. ==Efficiency== The efficiency and feasibility of this process depends on the efficiency of the compressing device (e.g., blower, compressor or steam ejector) and the [[heat transfer coefficient]] attained in the [[heat exchanger]] contacting the condensing vapor and the boiling "mother" solution/liquid. Theoretically, if the resulting condensate is [[subcooled]], this process could allow full recovery of the [[latent heat of vaporization]] that would otherwise be lost if the vapor, rather than the condensate, was the final product; therefore, this method of evaporation is very energy efficient. The [[evaporation]] process may be solely driven by the mechanical work provided by the compressing device. ==Some uses== ===Clean water production ([[Water for injection]])=== A vapor-compression evaporator, like most [[evaporator]]s, can make reasonably clean water from any water source. In a [[salt]] crystallizer, for example, a typical analysis of the resulting condensate shows a typical content of residual salt not higher than 50 [[Parts per million|ppm]] or, in terms of [[electrical conductance]], not higher than 10 [[siemens (unit)|μS/cm]]. This results in a drinkable water, if the other sanitary requirements are fulfilled. While this cannot compete in the marketplace with [[reverse osmosis]] or [[Desalination|demineralization]], vapor compression chiefly differs from these thanks to its ability to make clean water from saturated or even crystallizing brines with [[total dissolved solids]] (TDS) up to 650 g/L. The other two technologies can make clean water from sources no higher in TDS than approximately 35 g/L. For economic reasons evaporators are seldom operated on low-TDS water sources. Those applications are filled by reverse osmosis. The already brackish water which enters a typical evaporator is concentrated further. The increased dissolved solids act to increase the [[boiling point]] well beyond that of pure water. [[Seawater]] with a TDS of approximately 30 g/L exhibits a boiling point elevation of less than 1 [[Kelvin|K]] but saturated [[sodium chloride]] solution at 360 g/L has a boiling point elevation of about 7 K. This boiling point elevation represents a challenge for vapor-compression evaporation in that it increases the pressure ratio that the steam compressor must attain to effect vaporization. Since boiling point elevation determines the pressure ratio in the compressor, it is the main overall factor in operating costs. ===Steam-assisted gravity drainage=== The technology used today to extract bitumen from the [[Athabasca oil sands]] is the water-intensive [[steam-assisted gravity drainage]] (SAGD) method.{{citation |work=Air Water Land |date=October 2008 |accessdate=11 December 2014 |title=Watershed moment: SAGD operators embrace new water treatment options |first= Maurice |last=Smith |url=http://www.airwaterland.ca/article.asp?id=7354 }} In the late 1990s former nuclear engineer Bill Heins of [[General Electric Company]]'s RCC Thermal Products conceived an evaporator technology called falling film or mechanical vapor compression evaporation. In 1999 and 2002 [[Petro-Canada]]’s MacKay River facility was the first to install 1999 and 2002 GE SAGD [[zero-liquid discharge]] (ZLD) systems using a combination of the new evaporative technology and [[crystallizer system]] in which all the water was recycled and only solids were discharged off site. This new evaporative technology began to replace older water treatment techniques employed by SAGD facilities which involved the use of warm [[lime softening]] to remove [[silica]] and [[magnesium]] and weak acid cation [[ion exchange]] used to remove [[calcium]]. The vapor-compression evaporation process replaced the [[Heat recovery steam generator|once-through steam generators]] (OTSG) traditionally used for steam production. OTSG generally ran on [[natural gas]] which in 2008 had become increasingly valuable. The water quality of evaporators is four times better which is needed for the drum boilers. The evaporators, when coupled with standard drum boilers, produce steam which is more "reliable, less costly to operate, and less water-intensive." By 2008 about 85 per cent of SAGD facilities in the Alberta oil sands had adopted evaporative technology. "SAGD, unlike other thermal processes such as [[Steam injection (oil industry)|cyclic steam stimulation]] (CSS), requires 100 per cent quality steam." ==See also== * [[Cristiani compressed steam system]] * [[Slingshot (water vapor distillation system)]] * [[Vapor-compression refrigeration]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vapor-compression evaporation}} [[Category:Evaporators]] [[Category:Chemical processes]] [[Category:Unit operations]] [[Category:Water treatment]] [[Category:Water technology]]

revision.text:
The '''War on Cancer''' refers to the effort to find a cure for [[cancer]] by increased [[cancer research|research]] to improve the understanding of cancer biology and the development of more effective [[cancer treatments]], such as [[Targeted therapy|targeted drug therapies]]. The aim of such efforts is to eradicate cancer as a major [[cause of death]]. The signing of the National Cancer Act of 1971 by [[President of the United States|United States president]] [[Richard Nixon]] is generally viewed as the beginning of this effort, though it was not described as a "war" in the legislation itself.<ref name=NCAo71>{{cite web | url=http://www.cancer.gov/aboutnci/national-cancer-act-1971/allpages | title=National Cancer Act of 1971 | publisher=[[National Cancer Institute]] | accessdate=2009-08-09 }}</ref>
Despite significant progress in the treatment of certain forms of cancer (such as [[childhood leukemia]]<ref name=Kersey1997>{{cite journal | url=http://bloodjournal.hematologylibrary.org/cgi/content/full/90/11/4243 | title=Fifty Years of Studies of the Biology and Therapy of Childhood Leukemia | last=Kersey | first=John H. | journal=Blood | year=1997 | volume=90 | issue=11 | pages=4243–4251 | pmid=9373234 }}</ref>), cancer in general remains a major cause of death 40+ years after this war on cancer began,<ref name=Kolata2009_04>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/24/health/research/24cancerside.html | title=As Other Death Rates Fall, Cancer’s Scarcely Moves | last=Kolata | first=Gina | date=April 24, 2009 | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | accessdate=2009-06-10 }}</ref> leading to a perceived lack of progress<ref>[http://www.csicop.org/si/show/war_on_cancer_a_progress_report_for_skeptics The War on Cancer A Progress Report for Skeptics] Skeptical Inquirer, Volume 34.1, January / February 2010</ref><ref name=Hughes2006>{{Cite book | title=The War on Cancer: An Anatomy of Failure, a Blueprint for the Future (book review) | journal=[[Journal of the American Medical Association|JAMA]] | url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/short/295/24/2891 | author=Hughes R. | year=2006 | volume=295 | pages=2891–2892 | isbn=978-1-4020-3618-7 | doi=10.1001/jama.295.24.2891 | issue=24}}</ref><ref name=Begley2008>{{cite web | author=Sharon Begley | url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/157548 | title=Rethinking the War on Cancer | date=2008-09-15 | work=Newsweek | accessdate=2008-10-09}}</ref> and to new legislation aimed at augmenting the original National Cancer Act of 1971.<ref name=KenHutchBillNews>{{cite web | title=Kennedy, Hutchison Introduce Bill To Overhaul 1971 National Cancer Act | author= | url=http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/144105.php | date=2009-03-30 | accessdate=2009-03-30 | publisher=Medical News Today }}</ref> New research directions, in part based on the results of the [[Human Genome Project]], hold promise for a better understanding of the [[genetics|genetic]] factors underlying cancer, and the development of new diagnostics, therapies, [[Cancer#Prevention|preventive]] measures, and early detection ability. However, targeting cancer proteins can be difficult, as a protein can be [[Druggability#Undruggable targets|undruggable]].
== History == {{main article|History of Cancer}}
=== National Cancer Act of 1971 ===
{{external media | width = 210px | headerimage=[[File:Richard Nixon, official bw photo, head and shoulders.jpg|210px]] | float = right | video1 = [http://www.retroreport.org/video/the-long-war-on-cancer/ The Long War on Cancer], [[Retro Report]]<ref name="retrorep">{{Cite news | title =Hopeful Glimmers in Long War on Cancer| publisher =[[New York Times]] | date =November 4, 2013 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/04/booming/hopeful-glimmers-in-long-war-on-cancer.html?_r=0 | accessdate =August 25, 2015 | newspaper = The New York Times| last1 = Kolata| first1 = Gina}}</ref> }}
The war on cancer began with the National Cancer Act of 1971, a [[United States federal law]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://dtp.nci.nih.gov/timeline/noflash/milestones/M4_Nixon.htm | title=Milestone (1971): National Cancer Act of 1971 | work=Developmental Therapeutics Program Timeline | publisher=[[National Cancer Institute]] | accessdate=2009-08-09 }}</ref> The act was intended "to amend the [[Public Health Service Act]] so as to strengthen the [[National Cancer Institute]] in order to more effectively carry out the national effort against [[cancer]]".<ref name=NCAo71 /> It was signed into law by President Nixon on December 23, 1971.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://legislative.cancer.gov/history/phsa/1971 | title=National Cancer Act, Legislative History | work=Office of Government and Congressional Relations | publisher=[[National Cancer Institute]] | accessdate=2009-08-09 }}</ref>
Health activist and philanthropist [[Mary Lasker]] was instrumental in persuading the [[United States Congress]] to pass the National Cancer Act.<ref>{{cite book| title=The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer| last=Mukherjee| first=Siddhartha| isbn=978-1-4391-0795-9 | oclc=464593321| date=2010 | publisher=Simon & Schuster| location=New York}}</ref> She and her husband [[Albert Lasker]] were strong supporters of medical research. They established the Lasker Foundation which awarded people for their research. In the year of 1943, Mary Lasker began changing the American Cancer Society to get more funding for research. Five years later she contributed to getting federal funding for the National Cancer Institute and the National Heart Institute. In 1946 the funding was around $2.8 million and had grown to over $1.4 billion by 1972. In addition to all of these accomplishments, Mary became the president of the Lasker Foundation due to the death of her husband in 1952. Lasker's devotion to medical research and experience in the field eventually contributed to the passing of the National Cancer Act.<ref name="Credo Reference">{{cite web|last=Katz|first=Esther|title=LASKER, Mary Woodard Reinhardt. November 30, 1900-February 21, 1994|url=http://www.credoreference.com/entry.do?ta=hupnawiii&uh=lasker_mary_woodard_reinhardt_november_30_1900_february_21_1994|publisher=Cambridge: Harvard University Press|accessdate=16 September 2013}}</ref>
The improved funding for cancer research has been quite beneficial over the last 40 years. In 1971, the number of survivors in the U.S. was 3 million and as of 2007 has increased to more than 12 million.<ref name=EBSCOhost>{{cite web|last=Merenda|first=Christine|title=How Far Has the War on Cancer Come in the Past 40 Years?|url=http://web.ebscohost.com/ehost/detail?sid=c405b74c-cb7e-415f-8d40-ade419a216b5%40sessionmgr115&vid=3&hid=113&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZQ%3d%3d#db=afh&AN=79389124|publisher=ONS Connect|accessdate=20 September 2013}}</ref>
=== NCI Director's Challenge === In 2003, [[Andrew von Eschenbach]], the director of the [[National Cancer Institute]] (who served as FDA Commissioner from 2006-2009 and is now a Director at biotechnology company [[BioTime]]) issued a challenge "to eliminate the suffering and death from cancer, and to do so by 2015".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cancer.gov/directorscorner/directorsupdate-08-27-2003 | title=Director's Update: August 27, 2003: Eliminating Suffering and Death from Cancer by 2015: What Should NCI Contribute to the Challenge Goal? | accessdate=2008-11-05 | author=[[Andrew von Eschenbach]] }}</ref><!-- --><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.manhattan-institute.org/html/mpb_01.htm | title=Eliminating the Suffering and Death Due to Cancer by 2015 | author=Dr. Andrew von Eschenbach | publisher=[[Manhattan Institute for Policy Research]] | work=Medical Progress Bulletin, Issue 1 | date=September 2005 | accessdate=2009-06-13 }}</ref><!-- --> This was supported by the [[American Association for Cancer Research]] in 2005<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.aacr.org/home/public--media/science-policy--government-affairs/testimony/the-house-appropriations-subcommittee-on-labor,-health-and-human-services,-education-and-related-agencies-(2005).aspx | title=Written Testimony Submitted to The House Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and Related Agencies | author=Margaret Foti, Ph.D., M.D. | publisher=[[American Association for Cancer Research|AACR]] | date=2005-04-15 | accessdate=2009-06-13 }}</ref> though some scientists felt this goal was impossible to reach and undermined von Eschenbach's credibility.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Kaiser|first=Jocelyn | journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] | title=NCI Goal Aims for Cancer Victory by 2015 | date=28 February 2003 | volume=299|issue=5611|pages=1297–1298 |doi=10.1126/science.299.5611.1297b | url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/299/5611/1297.2 | accessdate=18 January 2011| pmid=12610266}}</ref>
[[John E. Niederhuber]], who succeeded Andrew von Eschenbach as NCI director, noted that cancer is a global health crisis, with 12.9 million new cases diagnosed in 2009 worldwide and that by 2030, this number could rise to 27 million including 17 million deaths "unless we take more pressing action."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cancer.gov/ncicancerbulletin/100609/page4 | title=Global Cancer Control: An Essential Duty | author=[[John E. Niederhuber]] | publisher=[[National Cancer Institute|NCI]] | work=NCI Cancer Bulletin | date=2009-10-06 | accessdate=2009-11-08 }}</ref>
[[Harold Varmus]], former director of the [[NIH]] and current director of the [[National Cancer Institute|NCI]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cancer.gov/ncicancerbulletin/071310/page2 | title=Harold Varmus Becomes Fourteenth Director of the National Cancer Institute | author=Bill Robinson | publisher=[[National Cancer Institute|NCI]] Cancer Bulletin | date=2010-07-12 | accessdate=2010-08-04 }}</ref><ref name=Varmus2010_scifri>{{cite web | url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=128568241 | title=Harold Varmus Returns To Politics | publisher=''[[Science Friday|NPR's Science Friday]]'' | date=2010-07-16 | accessdate=2010-08-04 }}</ref> held a town hall meeting in 2010<ref>{{cite video | title=Harold Varmus: NCI Town Hall Meeting (excerpts) | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wamffWRIdNQ | publisher=[[National Cancer Institute|NCI]] | date=2010-07-12 | accessdate=2010-08-04 }}</ref> in which he outlined his priorities for improving the cancer research program, including the following: # reforming the clinical trials system, # improving utilization of the NIH clinical center ([[Mark O. Hatfield Clinical Research Center]]), # readjusting the drug approval and regulation processes, # improving cancer treatment and prevention, and # formulating new, more specific and science-based questions.
=== Renewed focus on cancer ===
Recent years have seen an increased perception of a lack of progress in the war on cancer, and renewed motivation to confront the disease.<ref name=Hughes2006 /><ref>{{cite web | url=http://health.usnews.com/articles/health/cancer/2008/06/12/we-need-a-new-war-on-cancer.html | title=We Need a New War on Cancer | author=[[Bernadine Healy]] | date=2008-06-12 | publisher=[[U.S. News and World Report]] | accessdate=2009-10-26 }}</ref> On July 15, 2008, the [[United States Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions]] convened a panel discussion titled, ''Cancer: Challenges and Opportunities in the 21st Century''.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9YicA5ANMdE | title=Renewing the War on Cancer | format=video | author=[[Stand Up to Cancer]] | publisher=YouTube | date=2008-07-15 | accessdate=2009-01-30 }}</ref> It included interviews with noted [[cancer survivor]]s such as [[Arlen Specter]], [[Elizabeth Edwards]] and [[Lance Armstrong]], who came out of retirement in 2008, returning to competitive cycling "to raise awareness of the global cancer burden."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/cycling/2008-09-09-armstrong-comeback_N.htm | title=Armstrong coming out of retirement for another Tour | author=Sal Ruibal | publisher=[[USA Today]] | date=2008-09-10 | accessdate=2009-02-26 }}</ref>
===Livestrong Foundation=== The [[Livestrong Foundation]] created the Livestrong Global Cancer Campaign to address the burden of cancer worldwide and encourage nations to make commitments to battle the disease and provide better access to care.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livestrongaction.org/content/global-movement-end-cancer |title=A Global Movement To End Cancer |publisher=[[Lance Armstrong Foundation]] |accessdate=2009-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830070836/http://www.livestrongaction.org:80/content/global-movement-end-cancer |archivedate=2009-08-30 |df= }} {{third-party inline|date=July 2016}}</ref> In April 2009, the foundation announced that the [[Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan]] pledged $300 million to fund three important cancer control initiatives – building a cutting-edge cancer treatment and research facility, developing a national cancer control plan and creating an Office of Advocacy and Survivorship.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livestrong.org/site/apps/nlnet/content2.aspx?c=khLXK1PxHmF&b=2661079&ct=6924911 |title=LIVESTRONG Global Cancer campaign announces Hashemite Kingdom Of Jordan's commitment of $300 million to fund three cancer control initiatives. |date=2009-04-16 |accessdate=2009-04-16 |publisher=[[Lance Armstrong Foundation]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420015424/http://www.livestrong.org:80/site/apps/nlnet/content2.aspx?c=khLXK1PxHmF&b=2661079&ct=6924911 |archivedate=2009-04-20 |df= }}</ref> The Livestrong Foundation encourages similar commitments from other nations to combat the disease.
Livestrong Day is an annual event established by the LAF to serve as "a global day of action to raise awareness about the fight against cancer." Individuals from around the world are encouraged to host cancer-oriented events in their local communities and then register their events with the Livestrong website.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livestrongaction.org/map |title=LIVESTRONG Day home page |publisher=[[Lance Armstrong Foundation]] |accessdate=2009-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090927074634/http://www.livestrongaction.org:80/map |archivedate=2009-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
===21st Century Cancer Access to Life-Saving Early detection, Research and Treatment (ALERT) Act===
The [[United States Senate|US Senate]] on 26 March 2009 issued a new bill (S. 717), the [[21st Century Cancer Access to Life-Saving Early detection, Research and Treatment (ALERT) Act]]<ref>{{cite web | title=S.717: 21st Century Cancer ALERT (Access to Life-Saving Early detection, Research and Treatment) Act | url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s111-717 | publisher=GovTrack.us, 111th Congress (2009–2010) | date=2009-03-26 | author=Senators [[Ted Kennedy|Edward Kennedy]] and [[Kay Bailey Hutchison]] | accessdate=2009-03-30 }}</ref> intended to "overhaul the 1971 National Cancer Act."<ref name=KenHutchBillNews /> The bill aims to improve patient access to [[Cancer#Prevention|prevention]] and early detection by: # providing funding for research in early detection, # supplying grants for screening and referrals for treatment, and # increasing access to clinical trials and information.
===Obama-Biden Plan to Combat Cancer===
During their [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 U.S. presidential campaign]] then Senators [[Barack Obama]] and [[Joe Biden]] published a plan to combat cancer that entailed doubling "federal funding for cancer research within 5 years, focusing on [[NIH]] and [[National Cancer Institute|NCI]]" as well as working "with Congress to increase funding for the [[Food and Drug Administration]]."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.barackobama.com/pdf/issues/healthcare/Fact_Sheet_Cancer_FINAL.pdf | title=The Obama-Biden Plan To Combat Cancer | date=2008-09-06 | accessdate=2009-06-10 | publisher=[[Organizing for America]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://my.barackobama.com/page/community/post/seniors/gG5ctx | title=Obama-Biden release plan to combat cancer | author=The Senior Vote Team | date=2008-09-06 | accessdate=2009-06-10 | publisher=[[Organizing for America]] Community Blog }}</ref> Their plan would provide additional funding for: * research on rare cancers and those without effective treatment options, * the study of health disparities and evaluation of possible interventions, * and efforts to better understand genetic factors that can impact cancer onset and outcomes.
President Obama's [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009|2009 economic stimulus package]] includes $10 billion for the [[NIH]], which funds much of the [[cancer research]] in the U.S., and he has pledged to increase federal funding for cancer research by a third for the next two years as part of a drive to find "a cure for cancer in our time."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.scotsman.com/health/Obama--makes--.5206584.jp | title=Obama makes $10bn pledge to find cure for global killer 'in our time' | last=Foster | first=Kate | date=April 26, 2009 | publisher=''Scotsman.com News'' | accessdate=2009-06-10 }}</ref><!-- --><ref name=Kolata2009Advances>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/24/health/policy/24cancer.html | title=Advances Elusive in the Drive to Cure Cancer | last=Kolata | first=Gina | date=April 23, 2009 | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | accessdate=2009-06-10 }}</ref> In a message published in the July 2009 issue of [[Harper's Bazaar]], President Obama described his mother's battle with [[ovarian cancer]] and, noting the additional funding his administration has slated for cancer research, stated: "Now is the time to commit ourselves to waging a war against cancer as aggressive as the war cancer wages against us."<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090610074554/https://www.harpersbazaar.com/beauty/beauty-articles/barack-obama-ovarian-cancer | title=Ovarian Cancer: Fighting For A Cure | first=Christine | last=Lennon | journal=Harper's Bazaar | date=2009-06-03 | accessdate=2009-06-13 }}</ref> On 30 September 2009, Obama announced that $1 billion of a $5 billion medical research spending plan would be earmarked for research into the genetic causes of cancer and targeted cancer treatments.<ref name=obamaSep09>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-HealthcareReform/idUSTRE58T43G20090930 | title=Obama announces $5 billion for new medical research | last=Charles | first=Deborah | publisher=[[Reuters]] | date=2009-09-30 | accessdate=2009-10-01 }}</ref>
Cancer-related federal spending of money from the [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009|2009 Recovery Act]] can be tracked online.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.recovery.gov/espsearch/Pages/default.aspx?k=cancer | title=Recovery.gov: Track the Money ''(search term=cancer)'' | publisher=[[United States government]] | accessdate=2009-11-14 }}</ref>
===World Cancer Campaign===
The [[International Union Against Cancer|International Union Against Cancer (UICC)]] has organized a World Cancer campaign in 2009 with the theme, "I love my healthy active childhood," to promote healthy habits in children and thereby reduce their lifestyle-based cancer risk as adults.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.worldcancercampaign.org/ | title=World Cancer Campaign | publisher=[[International Union Against Cancer|UICC]] | accessdate=2009-10-16 }}</ref> The [[World Health Organization]] is also promoting this campaign<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.who.int/cancer/en/ | title= Cancer | accessdate=2009-10-16 | publisher=[[World Health Organization|WHO]] }}</ref> and joins with the UICC in annually promoting [[World Cancer Day]] on 4 February.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/events/annual/world_cancer_day/en/index.html | title=World Cancer Day | accessdate=2009-12-16 | publisher=[[World Health Organization|WHO]] }}</ref>
== Progress == Though there has been significant progress in the understanding of cancer biology, risk factors, [[cancer treatment|treatments]], and [[prognosis]] of some types of cancer (such as childhood leukemia<ref name=Kersey1997 />) since the inception of the National Cancer Act of 1971, progress in reducing the overall cancer [[mortality rate]] has been disappointing.<ref name=Hughes2006 /><ref name=Kolata2009Advances /> Many types of cancer remain largely incurable (such as pancreatic cancer<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cancer.gov/ncicancerbulletin/110309/page2 | title=Pancreatic Cancer Report Urges Changes in Clinical Trials | date=2009-11-03 | accessdate=2009-11-08 | publisher=[[National Cancer Institute|NCI]] | work=NCI Cancer Bulletin }}</ref>) and the overall death rate from cancer has not decreased appreciably since the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://seer.cancer.gov/csr/1975_2005/index.html | title=SEER Cancer Statistics Review, 1975–2005, National Cancer Institute. Bethesda, MD | author=Ries LAG, Melbert D, Krapcho M, Stinchcomb DG, Howlader N, Horner MJ, Mariotto A, Miller BA, Feuer EJ, Altekruse SF, Lewis DR, Clegg L, Eisner MP, Reichman M, Edwards BK (eds) | accessdate=2008-10-31 }}</ref> The death rate for cancer in the U.S., adjusted for population size and age, dropped only 5 percent from 1950 to 2005.<ref name=Kolata2009_04 /> Cancer was expected to surpass [[cardiovascular disease]] as the leading cause of death in the world by 2010, according to the [[World Health Organization]]'s ''World Cancer Report 2008''.<ref name=Reinberg_WaPo_2008>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/12/09/AR2008120901814.html | title=Cancer to Surpass Heart Disease as World's Leading Killer | last=Reinberg | first=Steven | date=2008-12-09 | accessdate=2009-08-30 | publisher=[[The Washington Post]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | url=http://apps.who.int/bookorders/anglais/detart1.jsp?sesslan=1&codlan=1&codcol=76&codcch=26 | title=World Cancer Report 2008 | last=Boyle | first=P. |author2=Levin B. | year=2008 | publisher=[[International Agency for Research on Cancer|IARC]] | pages=512 | isbn=978-92-832-0423-7 }}</ref> As of 2012, WHO reported 8.2 million annual deaths from cancer<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.who.int/cancer/en/ | title=WHO: Cancer | accessdate=2014-07-05}}</ref> Heart disease (including both Ischaemic and hypertensive) accounted for 8.5 million annual deaths. Stroke accounted for 6.7 million annual deaths. <ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs310/en/ | accessdate=2014-07-05 | title=WHO: The Top 10 Causes of Death}}</ref>
There is evidence for progress in reducing cancer mortality.<ref name=SciDailyProgress2010>{{cite news | url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/03/100316101556.htm | title=Progress Has Been Made in War on Cancer, but Still Many Challenges | publisher=[[Science Daily]] | date=2010-03-19 | accessdate=2010-03-19 }}</ref> Age-specific analysis of cancer mortality rates has had progress in reducing cancer mortality in the United States since 1955. An August 2009 study found that age-specific cancer mortality rates have been steadily declining since the early 1950s for individuals born since 1925, with the youngest age groups experiencing the steepest decline in mortality rate at 25.9 percent per decade, and the oldest age groups experiencing a 6.8 percent per decade decline.<ref>{{cite journal | title=The Decline in U.S. Cancer Mortality in People Born since 1925 | first=Eric J. | last=Kort |author2=Nigel Paneth |author3=George F. Vande Woude | date=2009-08-15 | journal=[[Cancer Research (journal)|Cancer Research]] | volume=69 | issue=16 | doi=10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-09-0357 | pages=6500–5 | pmid=19679548 | pmc=4326089 }}</ref> Dr. Eric Kort, the lead author of this study, claims that public reports often focus on cancer incidence rates and underappreciate the progress that has been achieved in reduced cancer mortality rates.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2009-08/aafc-cmr080609.php | title=Cancer mortality rates experience steady decline | date=2009-08-13 | last=Moore | first=Jeremy | publisher=[[EurekAlert]] | accessdate=2009-08-30 }}</ref>
The effectiveness and expansion of available therapies has seen significant improvements since the 1970s. For example, [[lumpectomy]] replaced more invasive [[mastectomy]] surgery for the treatment of [[breast cancer]].<ref name=WagingWar101 /> Treatment of childhood leukemia<ref name=Kersey1997 /> and [[chronic myeloid leukemia]] (CML) have undergone major advances since the war on cancer began. The drug [[Gleevec]] now cures most CML patients, compared to previous therapy with [[interferon]], which extended life for approximately 1 year in only 20-30 percent of patients.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/03/science/03conv.html | title=Researcher Behind the Drug Gleevec: A Conversation with Brian K. Druker, M.D. | author=[[Claudia Dreifus]] | publisher=[[The New York Times|NYTimes]] | date=2009-11-02 | accessdate=2009-11-03 | newspaper=The New York Times }}</ref>
Dr. [[Steven Rosenberg]], chief of surgery at the [[National Cancer Institute|NCI]] has said that as of the year 2000, 50% of all diagnosed cases of cancer are curable through a combination of [[surgery]], [[radiation therapy|radiation]], and [[chemotherapy]].<ref name=WagingWar101>{{cite episode | title = History of Cancer | episodelink = | series = [http://wagingwaroncancer.com/ Waging War on Cancer] | serieslink = | airdate = 2009-08-23 | season = | number = 101}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0001/02/se.20.html | title=Millennium 2000: Cancer (transcript) | publisher=[[CNN]] | date=2000-01-02 | accessdate=2009-10-15 }}</ref> Cancer surveillance experts have reported a 15.8 percent decrease in the age-standardized death rate from all cancers combined between 1991 and 2006 along with an approximately 1 percent annual decrease in the rate of new diagnoses between 1999 and 2006.<ref name=SciDailyProgress2010 /> A large portion of this decreased mortality for men was attributable to [[smoking cessation]] efforts in the United States.
A 2010 report from the [[American Cancer Society]] found that death rates for all cancers combined decreased 1.3% per year from 2001 to 2006 in males and 0.5% per year from 1998 to 2006 in females, largely due to decreases in the 3 major cancer sites in men (lung, prostate, and colorectum) and 2 major cancer sites in women (breast and colorectum). Cancer death rates between 1990 and 2006 for all races combined decreased by 21.0% among men and by 12.3% among women. This reduction in the overall cancer death rates translates to the avoidance of approximately 767,000 deaths from cancer over the 16-year period. Despite these reductions, the report noted, cancer still accounts for more deaths than [[heart disease]] in persons younger than 85 years.<ref>{{cite journal | journal=CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians | last1=Jemal | volume=60 | title=Cancer Statistics, 2010 | issue=5 | pages=277–300 | first1=A | last2=Siegel | first2=R | last3=Xu | first3=J | last4=Ward | first4=E | author9=Jemal A, Siegel R, Xu J, Ward E | date=2010-07-07 | pmid=20610543 | doi=10.3322/caac.20073 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.webmd.com/cancer/news/20100708/cancer-death-rates-are-dropping-in-u-s | title=Cancer Death Rates Are Dropping in U.S. | author=Bill Hendrick | publisher=[[WebMD]] Health News | date=2010-07-08 | accessdate=2010-08-03 }}</ref>
An improvement in the number of cancer survivors living in the U.S. was indicated in a 2011 report by the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] and the [[National Cancer Institute|NCI]], which noted that the number of cancer survivors in 2007 (11.7 million) increased by 19% from 2001 (9.8 million survivors). The number of cancer survivors in 1971 was 3 million. [[Breast cancer|Breast]], [[Prostate cancer|prostate]], and [[Colorectal cancer|colorectal]] cancers were the most common types of cancer among survivors, accounting for 51% of diagnoses. As of January 1, 2007, an estimated 64.8% of cancer survivors had lived ≥5 years after their diagnosis of cancer, and 59.5% of survivors were aged ≥65 years.<ref>{{cite web |title=Cancer Survivors --- United States, 2007 |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6009a1.htm?s_cid=mm6009a1_w|work=Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR) |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] |accessdate=14 March 2011 |pages=269–272 |date=11 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Belluck |first=Pam |title=20% Rise Seen in Number of Survivors of Cancer |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/11/health/11cancer.html |accessdate=14 March 2011 |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=10 March 2011 }}</ref> A continued decline in cancer rates in the U.S. among both women and men, across most major racial groups, and in the most common cancer sites (lung, colon and rectum), was indicated in a 2013 report by the National Cancer Institute. However, the same report indicated an increase from 2000 to 2009 in cancers of the liver, pancreas and uterus.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.healthimaging.com/topics/oncology-imaging/us-cancer-death-rates-dip | title=Cancer U.S. cancer rates dip | author=Editorial Staff | publisher=TriMed Media | date=2013-01-08 | accessdate=2013-01-09 }}</ref>
===Challenges=== A multitude of factors have been cited as impeding progress in finding a cure for cancer<ref name=Hughes2006/><ref name=Begley2008/> and key areas have been identified and suggested as important to accelerate progress in cancer research.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cancer.gov/think-tanks-cancer-biology | title=NCI Think Tanks in Cancer Biology | year=2004 | publisher=[[National Cancer Institute|NCI]] | accessdate=2009-10-27 }}</ref> Since there are many different forms of cancer with distinct causes, each form requires different treatment approaches. However, this research could still lead to therapies and cures for many forms of cancer. Some of the factors that have posed challenges for the development of [[Cancer#Prevention|preventive]] measures and anti-cancer drugs and therapies include the following:
* Inherent biological complexity of the disease: ** number of changes within a cell leading to the cancerous state<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/understandingcancer/geneticvariation/Slide2 | title=Cancer - A Complex Disease | work=Understanding Cancer Series: Genetic Variation (SNPs) | ==Modern cancer research==
===Genome-based cancer research projects=== The rise of a new class of [[molecular biology|molecular]] technologies developed during the [[Human Genome Project]] opens up new ways to study cancer and holds the promise for the discovery of new aspects of cancer biology that could eventually lead to novel, more effective diagnostics and therapies for cancer patients.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cancerdiagnosis.nci.nih.gov/challenge/index.htm |title=NCI Director's Challenge: Toward a Molecular Classification of Cancer |accessdate=2008-11-05 |work=NCI's Cancer Diagnosis Program |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704052940/http://www.cancerdiagnosis.nci.nih.gov/challenge/index.htm |archivedate=July 4, 2008 }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web | url=http://health.usnews.com/articles/health/cancer/2008/10/23/breaking-cancers-gene-code.html | author=Bernadine Healy M.D. | work=U.S. News & World Report | date=2008-10-23 | title=Breaking Cancer's Gene Code | accessdate=2008-10-28}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web | url=http://plan.cancer.gov/Empowering_Cancer_Research.htm | title=Empowering Cancer Research | work=[[National Cancer Institute|NCI]]'s "The Nation's Investment in Cancer Research" | accessdate=2008-11-05 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080616063930/http://plan.cancer.gov/Empowering_Cancer_Research.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-06-16}}</ref> These new technologies are capable of screening many [[biomolecules]] and [[Genetics|genetic]] variations such as [[single nucleotide polymorphisms|SNPs]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/understandingcancer/geneticvariation/Slide3 | title=SNPs May Be The Solution | publisher=[[National Cancer Institute]] | work=Understanding Cancer Series: Genetic Variation (SNPs) | date=2006-09-01 | accessdate=2009-10-16 }}</ref> and [[copy number variation]]s in a single experiment and are employed within [[functional genomics]] and [[personalized medicine]] studies.
Speaking on the occasion of the announcement of $1 billion in new funding for genome-based cancer research, Dr. [[Francis Collins (geneticist)|Francis Collins]], director of the [[NIH]] claimed, "We are about to see a quantum leap in our understanding of cancer."<ref name=obamaSep09 /> [[Harold Varmus]], after his appointment to be the director of the [[National Cancer Institute|NCI]], said we are in a "golden era for cancer research," poised to profit from advances in our understanding of the cancer genome.<ref name=Varmus2010_scifri />
[[High-throughput sequencing|High-throughput DNA sequencing]] has been used to study the whole genome sequence of two different cancer tissues: a [[small-cell lung cancer]] [[metastasis]] and a [[malignant melanoma]] cell line.<ref>{{cite journal | title=A comprehensive catalogue of somatic mutations from a human cancer genome | url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nature08658.html | last= Pleasance | first=Erin D. | year=2009 | doi=10.1038/nature08658 | journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume=463 | last2=Cheetham | first2=R. ====The Cancer Genome Atlas==== [[The Cancer Genome Atlas]] (TCGA), a collaborative effort between the [[National Cancer Institute]] and the [[National Human Genome Research Institute]], is an example of a basic research project that is employing some of these new molecular approaches.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://cancergenome.nih.gov/index.asp | title=The Cancer Genome Atlas website | work=[[National Cancer Institute]] and the [[National Human Genome Research Institute]] | accessdate=2009-02-14 }}</ref> One TCGA publication notes the following: <blockquote> ''Here we report the interim integrative analysis of [[Copy number variation|DNA copy number]], [[gene expression]] and [[DNA methylation]] aberrations in 206 [[glioblastoma]]s...Together, these findings establish the feasibility and power of TCGA, demonstrating that it can rapidly expand knowledge of the molecular basis of cancer.''<ref>{{cite journal | title=Comprehensive genomic characterization defines human glioblastoma genes and core pathways | date=2008-10-23 | journal=Nature | url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/vaop/ncurrent/abs/nature07385.html | volume=455 | pages=1061–1068 | doi=10.1038/nature07385 | pmid=18772890 | issue=7216 | pmc=2671642 | last2=Friedman | first2=Allan | last3=Bigner | first3=Darrell | last4=Van Meir | first4=Erwin G. | last5=Brat | first5=Daniel J. | last6=M. In a cancer research funding announcement made by president Obama in September 2009, TCGA project is slated to receive $175 million in funding to collect comprehensive gene sequence data on 20,000 tissue samples from people with more than 20 different types of cancer, in order to help researchers understand the genetic changes underlying cancer. New, targeted therapeutic approaches are expected to arise from the insights resulting from such studies.<ref name=obamaSep09 />
====Cancer Genome Project==== The [[Cancer Genome Project]] at the [[Sanger Institute|Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute]] aims to identify [[genetic variation|sequence variant]]s/[[mutation]]s critical in the development of human [[cancer]]s. The Cancer Genome Project combines knowledge of the [[human genome]] sequence with [[high-throughput screening|high throughput mutation detection]] techniques.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/genetics/CGP/ |title=The Cancer Genome Project website |work=Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute |accessdate=2009-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130702205644/http://www.sanger.ac.uk/genetics/CGP/ |archivedate=2013-07-02 |df= }}</ref>
===Cancer research supportive infrastructure=== Advances in [[information technology]] supporting cancer research, such as the [[National Cancer Institute|NCI]]'s [[caBIG]] project, promise to improve data sharing among cancer researchers and accelerate "the discovery of new approaches for the detection, diagnosis, treatment, and [[Cancer#Prevention|prevention]] of cancer, ultimately improving patient outcomes."<ref>{{cite web | title=About caBIG | url=https://cabig.nci.nih.gov/overview/ | publisher=[[National Cancer Institute|NCI]]'s cancer Biomedical Informatics Grid website | accessdate=2008-12-06 }}</ref>
==Modern cancer treatment==
===Cancer clinical trials=== Researchers are considering ways to improve the efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and overall success rate of cancer clinical trials.<ref>{{cite book | title= Improving the Quality of Cancer Clinical Trials: Workshop Summary | url=http://books.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_id=12146 | isbn=978-0-309-11668-8 | year=2008 | pages=136 | last1= Patlak | first1= Margie | last2= Nass | first2= Sharyl }}</ref>
Increased participation in rigorously designed clinical trials would increase the pace of research. Currently, about 3% of people with cancer participate in clinical trials; more than half of them are patients for whom no other options are left, patients who are participating in "exploratory" trials designed to burnish the researchers' résumés or promote a drug rather than to produce meaningful information, or in trials that will not enroll enough patients to produce a [[statistically significant]] result.{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}}
===Targeted tumor treatment=== A major challenge in cancer treatment is to find better ways to specifically target tumors with drugs and [[chemotherapy|chemotherapeutic agents]] in order to provide a more effective, localized dose and to minimize exposure of healthy tissue in other parts of the body to the potentially adverse effects of the treatments. The accessibility of different tissues and organs to anti-tumor drugs contributes to this challenge. For example, the [[blood–brain barrier]] blocks many drugs that may otherwise be effective against brain tumors. In November 2009, a new, experimental therapeutic approach for treating [[glioblastoma]] was published in which the anti-tumor drug [[Avastin]] was delivered to turmor site within the brain through the use of [[catheter|microcatheters]], along with [[mannitol]] to temporarily open the blood–brain barrier permitting delivery of the chemotherapy into the brain.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/17/health/17tumor.html | title=Breaching a Barrier to Fight Brain Cancer | last=Grady | first=Denise | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | date=2009-11-16 | accessdate=2009-12-20 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/11/091117102048.htm | title=World's First Delivery of Intra-Arterial Avastin Directly Into Brain Tumor | publisher=[[Science Daily]] | date=2009-11-17 | accessdate=2009-12-20 }}</ref>
==Public education and support== An important aspect to the war on cancer is improving public access to educational and supportive resources, to provide individuals with the latest information about cancer [[Cancer#Prevention|prevention]] and [[Management of cancer|treatment]], as well as access to support communities. Resources have been created by governmental and other organizations to provide support for cancer patients, their families and caregivers, to help them share information and find advice to guide decision making.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cancer.gov/aboutnci/cis | title=Cancer Information Service | publisher=[[National Cancer Institute|NCI]] | accessdate=2009-10-18 }}</ref><ref> {{cite web | url=http://www.cancer.org/docroot/AA/content/AA_2_8_NCIC_1-800-227-2345.asp | title=Need Answers? 1-800-227-2345 | publisher=[[American Cancer Society|ACS]] | accessdate=2009-11-08 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.cdc.gov/cancer/ | title=Cancer Prevention and Control | publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] | accessdate=2010-12-27 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.who.int/cancer/en/ | title=World Health Organization's Cancer website | publisher=[[World Health Organization|WHO]] | accessdate=2010-12-27 }}</ref><ref> {{cite web | url=http://www.cancercompass.com/ | title=Cancer Compass, Community for cancer patients & caregivers. | accessdate=2010-12-27 }}</ref><ref> {{cite web | url=http://csn.cancer.org/forum | title=Cancer Survivors Network | publisher=[[American Cancer Society|ACS]] | accessdate=2010-12-27 }}</ref><ref> {{cite web | url=http://www.cancertv.net/ | title=CancerTV | accessdate=2010-12-27 }}</ref>
